[HEADING] Project Abstract Summary

[TEXT] This Project Abstract Summary form must be submitted or the application will be considered incomplete. Ensure the Project Abstract field succinctly describes the project in plain language that the public can understand and use without the full proposal. Use 4,000 characters or less. Do not include personally identifiable, sensitive or proprietary information. Refer to Agency instructions for any additional Project Abstract field requirements. If the application is funded, your project abstract information (as submitted) will be made available to public websites and/or databases including USAspending.gov.

[HEADING] Project Abstract

[TEXT] Project Title: Community Clinic of Maui, Inc .: Comprehensive primary care, dental, and behavioral health services for underserved residents of Maui. Project Director Name: John Vaz Applicant Organization Name: Community Clinic of Maui, Inc. HRSA Award Number: H80CS00722 SAC ID: 187 NOFO: HRSA-26-005 Contact Number: 808-872-4018 Address: 1881 Nani Street, Wailuku, HI 96793 Email Address: jvaz@ccmaui.org Websi www.ccmaui.org Project Abstract Community Clinic of Maui, Inc. (CCM), a 501(c)(3) Federally Qualified Health Center founded in 1993, provides accessible, comprehensive, and preventive primary care services for underserved and high-needs populations across Maui County. CCM serves all federally designated underserved ZIP codes in the Service Area Announcement Table (SAAT), reaching more than 13,000 patients annually. As the only safety-net provider outside of Hana offering integrated medical, behavioral health, substance use treatment, and dental care, CCM emphasizes cultural sensitivity, prevention, education, and advocacy to reduce health disparities. CCM's main site is in Wailuku, with additional locations at the Central Maui Homeless Resource Center, three school-based health centers, and a West Maui site relocated to Kahana following the 2023 wildfires. Services include adult and pediatric primary care, obstetrics/gynecology, maternal-fetal medicine, psychiatry, behavioral health, medication-assisted treatment, substance use services, oral health, nutrition education, and outreach. To ensure access regardless of ability to pay, CCM offers discounts for patients up to 200% of the federal poverty level. CCM also addresses social determinants of health through programs supporting housing, food security, transportation, and language access. CCM maintains Patient-Centered Medical Home (PCMH) recognition and has been recognized by HRSA as a Community Health Center Quality Leader, Health Disparities Reducer, and Access Enhancer, underscoring our commitment to high-quality care, reducing disparities, and expanding access for Maui's most vulnerable residents.

[HEADING] NEED

[TEXT] 1. Describe the proposed service area (consistent with Attachment 1: Service Area Map and Table), including:

[HEADING] a. The service area boundaries.

[TEXT] Maui County includes three islands: Maui, Molokai and Lanai. The Community Clinic of Maui, Inc.'s (CCM's) service area primarily encompasses Census Tracts 303-315 on the island of Maui. While these tracts define our HRSA targeted service area, limited healthcare resources in Maui County bring patients from other areas to CCM for care. Maui is comprised of the following major districts:

[TEXT] · Central Maui- Wailuku and Kahului

[TEXT] · South Maui- Kihei and Wailea

[TEXT] · West Maui- Lahaina, Kaanapali, Napili, and Kapalua

[TEXT] · Upcountry Maui- Makawao, Pukalani, and Kula

[TEXT] . North Shore- Paia and Haiku

[TEXT] There is little overlap with the other designated rural systems in the county such as Hana Health, Lanai Community Health Center, and Molokai Community Health Center, because of their geographic separation. Residents of Molokai and Lanai must travel by plane or boat to the island of Maui, while Hana Health is at least a two-hour winding drive from census tracts outside of 301. When specialty services are needed, such as obstetric care, CCM collaborates with these systems to ensure patients can access resources not otherwise available at their locations.

[HEADING] b. If it is located in an Opportunity Zone.

[TEXT] CCM's main location is within Census Tract 309.01 which is designated as a Qualified Opportunity Zone under the U.S. Department of the Treasury (IRS, 2018, Notice 2018-48). According to U.S. Census Bureau data (Data Commons, 2023), the population in the opportunity zone is 2,127.

[HEADING] c. How the boundaries of the service area ensure that services are available and accessible to the residents of the area.

[TEXT] The service area boundaries encompass the central, west, and south regions of Maui, aligning with major population centers and public transportation routes to ensure that all residents can readily access primary care services. Malama I Ke Ola Health Center's main site in Wailuku sits at the island's geographic center, within 20-30 minutes of most residential areas served, while satellite sites in Lahaina and Kihei extend access to residents in more remote or traffic-impacted areas. Parts of ZIP codes 96708, 96790, and 96768 are designated medically underserved areas; these communities are within a one-hour drive to Wailuku compared to a two-hour drive along the winding road to Hana, making CCM's clinics the more accessible option for care.

[TEXT] d. How the overlap of political subdivisions, school districts, and areas served by Federal and State health and social programs affect access to primary health care services in the service area.

[TEXT] The service area spans multiple political subdivisions and school districts, but boundaries do not limit access to care because CCM's sites are centrally located and accessible to residents across these jurisdictions. The main clinic is located near county and state buildings where benefit offices such as SNAP and Unemployment are housed, within a two-minute drive from the MedQUEST office and five minutes from WIC, and within walking distance of a public housing site. The Ka Hale A Ke Ola (KHAO) satellite site is located within the homeless shelter, adjacent to public housing, supporting seamless access to both health care and social services. Maui High School-based Health Center is also located near a public housing complex, and the Kihei School-based Health Center operates within a Title I school serving low-income families. Together, these locations strengthen care coordination and ensure that residents in high-need areas can easily reach comprehensive primary care and enabling services.

[TEXT] e. How you will annually review the proposed service area to identify where your patients reside, available health resources, and unmet need.

[TEXT] CCM evaluates access to care for Maui residents through community health needs assessments, survey data collection, and analysis of annual UDS data. Each year, CCM reviews patient origin by ZIP code to identify where patients reside relative to available health resources and to detect emerging areas of unmet need. This review informs strategic planning discussions on whether expanding services through an additional site is financially and operationally justified, or if access barriers can be more effectively addressed through enabling services such as transportation assistance, outreach, or care coordination.

[TEXT] f. If your urban/rural selection on Form 1A is different from the service area type listed for the proposed service area on the SAAT, explain why, including data sources.

[TEXT] Our selection on Form 1A is consistent with the proposed service area on the SAAT. g. Competing continuation applicants: Using Uniform Data System (UDS) data, describe changes to the service area since your last SAC application.

[TEXT] Community Clinic of Maui, Inc. H80CS00722

[TEXT] EHB Application Number: 243040

[TEXT] Grant Number: 6 H80CS00722-24-07

[TEXT] Using Uniform Data System (UDS) data, CCM observed notable shifts in patient distribution and service utilization between 2022 and 2024. Following the 2023 Lahaina wildfires, there was a 65 percent decrease in patients from the Lahaina area, accompanied by corresponding increases in patients residing in Central, South, and Upcountry Maui as displaced residents relocated.

[TEXT] Overall, total patients served increased from 11,564 in 2022 to 13,471 in 2024, reflecting expanded service reach and population movement across the island. Obstetrics services grew significantly following the closure of the only other private obstetrics office for non Kaiser- insured women on Maui, with provider FTEs increasing by approximately 2.0 and encounters rising from 7,414 in 2022 to 10,438 in 2023 and 11,871 in 2024, demonstrating sustained growth in prenatal and women's health demand. Adult medicine visits remained steady during this period, while pediatric encounters increased from 6,325 to 9,076, supported by an additional 1.2 FTE, largely driven by school-based health center expansion and post-disaster family relocations.

[TEXT] 2. Describe health care needs in the announced service area, including those that you are meeting or which are met by the current Health Center Program award recipient. If your service area includes HP, RPH, and/or MSAW funding, include the needs of each special medically underserved population. Address needs related to the following:

[TEXT] a. Comprehensive primary health care services, including in-scope nutrition, chronic disease management, preventive health education, cancer screening, and mental health services.

[TEXT] As shown in CCM's Service Area Map and Table (Attachment 1), HRSA designates portions of Maui County as Medically Underserved Areas (MUAs) and Medically Underserved Populations (MUPs). Note that the U.S. Census data for Maui County combines the populations of Maui, Lanai, and Molokai, and cannot be disaggregated by individual islands. As reported by the U.S. Census Bureau (2024) the estimated population in Maui County was 163,688, reflecting a slight decrease from 164,244 in 2023. This decline may have been due to the displacement of residents following the 2023 Maui Wildfires.

[TEXT] Maui County's population is evenly divided between males and females, with about 60 percent in their working years (ages 18-64) and 22 percent over age 65. Nearly one in five residents is foreign-born; of these, 44 percent are non-U.S. citizens and the remainder are naturalized U.S. citizens. Reflecting this diversity, about one in five households speak a language other than English at home.

[TEXT] In Maui County, only 36 percent of households have attained a bachelor's degree or higher, and the median household income is $101,192. Yet one in ten households live in poverty, showing clear income gaps. About six percent of adults are covered by Medicaid, while five percent remain uninsured. Among children, four percent also lack health insurance.

[HEADING] Health Disparities

[TEXT] Hawaii Health Matters reports that 26.1 percent of adults (age 18+) in Maui County are obese (Hawaii Health Matters, 2023). Among this population, the majority of those affected are Native Hawaiian. 15 percent of teens are obese, the majority of those being Pacific Islander.

[TEXT] 3

[TEXT] Community Clinic of Maui, Inc. H80CS00722

[TEXT] EHB Application Number: 243040

[HEADING] Diabetes

[TEXT] In Maui County, 12.1 percent of adults are diagnosed with diabetes, not significantly different from the rates for Hawaii and the United States overall (Hawaii Health Matters, 2023). Native Hawaiians experience the highest mortality rate from diabetes.

[TEXT] Within CCM's patient population, 13 percent of Pacific Islander patients and 11 percent of Asian patients within their respective groups are diagnosed with diabetes, substantially higher than Native Hawaiians at 8 percent and White patients at 4 percent, indicating that, proportionally, these populations experience a greater burden of chronic disease compared to other groups served. Pacific Islanders in Maui also experience lower household incomes, often due to language barriers and challenges assimilating into the local economic culture, which can limit access to consistent care.

[TEXT] The Hawai'i Department of Business, Economic Development & Tourism reported that among full-time year-round workers in Hawaii, Pacific Islander workers earned less than $35,000 annually, significantly lower than many other racial/ethnic groups. Addressing prevention and management of diabetes, especially within this population, is especially critical given Maui's limited healthcare resources; without effective chronic disease management at the community level, preventable complications increase demand on the island's already strained hospital and specialty care systems.

[HEADING] Hypertension and Stroke Mortality

[TEXT] Maui County experiences a substantially higher stroke mortality rate than both Hawaii and the United States overall. The age-adjusted death rate due to stroke in Maui County is 51.1 per 100,000 population, compared with 38.8 for Hawaii and 39.0 for the United States (Hawaii Health Matters, 2023). Filipinos and Native Hawaiians have the highest incidence of stroke- related deaths in Maui.

[TEXT] When comparing hypertension diagnoses by ethnic group relative to each group's proportion within CCM's total patient population, Asian (including Filipino) and Black patients show the highest rates, with 20 percent of patients within each group diagnosed. American Indian patients follow at 16 percent, while 14 percent of Native Hawaiian and Other Pacific Islander patients have been diagnosed. White and multiracial patients each show a 12 percent rate.

[TEXT] However, despite the higher stroke mortality rate, the prevalence of hypertension in Maui County is lower than that of Hawaii and the United States overall, with 30.3 percent in Maui County, 32.4 percent in Hawaii, and 34 percent in the United States. This pattern likely reflects differences in healthcare access, early detection, and continuity of treatment rather than true differences in underlying risk, as limited specialty and emergency resources may contribute to poorer outcomes for those diagnosed.

[TEXT] While Maui's hospital is designated as a Primary Stroke Center, it lacks the advanced capabilities and resources of Honolulu's Comprehensive Stroke Center, requiring most complex stroke cases to be transferred off-island for higher-level care. This makes effective chronic disease management and preventive care especially critical to reduce the incidence and severity of conditions such as hypertension and stroke, which can overwhelm both limited local

[HEADING] healthcare capacity and family financial resources, further widening existing economic disparities.

[HEADING] Cancer

[TEXT] Maui County's overall cancer incidence and mortality rates are not significantly higher than state or national averages; however, disparities persist in access to timely screening and diagnosis, particularly among low-income and rural residents. Limited specialty care availability, high travel costs, and long distances to diagnostic services contribute to delayed detection and poorer outcomes. Cancer screening is a fundamental component of comprehensive primary and preventive care, yet many patients struggle to complete follow-up appointments without additional support. The critical need extends beyond access to screening itself to the guidance, coordination, and reassurance CCM provides to help patients navigate the process, understand results, and follow through with recommended care.

[HEADING] Mental Health

[TEXT] Mental health needs on Maui have intensified in the aftermath of the 2023 wildfires, with recent data showing alarming levels of distress among residents. According to a University of Hawai'i at Mānoa study, 55 percent of Maui participants reported depressive symptoms, a sharp increase from the 33 percent previously reported for both the state and the island. A separate study by the Hawai'i State Rural Health Association found that 76 percent of participants felt more "worried" than "hopeful" about their future on Maui, with heightened concern among women, younger adults, Native Hawaiian, Pacific Islander, and Filipino residents, and families with children. Teachers and administrators at local schools where CCM operates school-based health centers consistently identify mental health as the most urgent need, reporting that students exhibiting disruptive or trauma-related behaviors often have no access to counseling and are instead sent home, further disrupting learning and stability.

[HEADING] Culturally Competent Care

[TEXT] Maui's diverse population makes culturally competent primary care and health education essential to improving health outcomes. CCM serves patients from many ethnic and cultural backgrounds, each with distinct beliefs, languages, and experiences that influence how they perceive and engage with care. Effective care depends not only on clinical quality but also on cultural understanding and trust. When patients feel seen, heard, and respected, they are more likely to participate in preventive care, adhere to treatment, and seek help early. Without culturally competent approaches, even the best medical interventions may fail to reach their intended impact.

[HEADING] Nutrition

[TEXT] Maui County does not experience disparities in fruit and vegetable consumption compared to the U.S. value (America's Health Rankings, 2024). While healthy food options are available in Maui County, financial stability, time constraints, and stress strongly influence dietary choices. The Maui Together Wildfire Assessment (Grove, 2024) found that 60 percent of residents had reduced spending on food and groceries for financial reasons.

[TEXT] Hawaii's family-oriented culture, where multigenerational households are common, adds complexity to meal preparation. Nutrition education and counseling must therefore address the realities of limited time, budget pressures, and the need to prepare meals that appeal to a range of ages and preferences within larger households. Preparing healthy meals on a budget often requires time to plan, compare prices, and shop at multiple stores, an unrealistic expectation for many households already short on time. As food and grocery costs continue to rise in Maui, choosing healthier options becomes increasingly difficult compared to the convenience and perceived affordability of less nutritious foods.

[TEXT] b. Patient support services (for example, services that enable patients to access health center services, health and nutrition education services, and case management and care coordination services that can address health-related social factors such as those related to food insecurity, housing insecurity, and financial strain).

[TEXT] A study at the University of Hawaii has been ongoing since 2022, with a new report published yearly, designed to reflect the state's diverse demographics. One of the study participants states, "Health in Hawaii has been declining. Not because people are getting sicker, but it's really because our system is failing to meet their basic needs like food, housing, and mental health care. And this is especially obvious for the Native Hawaiians, Pacific Islanders, and low-income communities."

[HEADING] Financial Strain

[TEXT] Hawaii has the highest overall cost of living index in the nation, exceeding the next most expensive states by more than 40 points (World Population Review, 2024). The state also ranks first in housing costs and third in health care costs nationwide.

[TEXT] Maui residents face significant financial strain. The median home price reached $1.37 million in late 2024, while rents average $2,350 to $4,000 per month, and basic utilities add about $475 monthly. With average hourly wages around $17, many households spend a large share of their income on housing, food, and transportation, leaving little for medical expenses. Rising grocery costs, about 32 percent above the national average, further compound financial pressure. These realities make it common for residents to postpone or forgo care. CCM helps alleviate this burden by offering affordable primary care and a sliding fee scale for self-pay patients, along with transportation coordination and assistance with benefit and resource applications. By helping patients manage appointments efficiently and maintain continuity of care, CCM reduces

[HEADING] Transportation

[TEXT] Maui's high cost of living and dispersed geography limit access to care, with most health services concentrated in Central Maui and residents in other districts traveling up to 55 miles for appointments. Limited public transit and the high cost of car ownership make transportation a major barrier, especially for low-income households. CCM addresses this through transportation coordination and contracted ride services to help patients reach care.

[HEADING] Housing

[TEXT] In August 2023, the Maui wildfires destroyed more than 2,000 structures and displaced thousands of residents, primarily from Lahaina. Many people lost their homes, cars, businesses, and jobs. Following the wildfires, displaced residents experienced significant disruptions to stability and daily routines, increasing their reliance on patient support services to maintain access to care. Many relocated to Central Maui or moved into temporary FEMA-supported or modular housing units in West Maui, where living conditions-though ADA-compliant-often remain difficult for individuals with limited mobility or chronic health conditions.

[TEXT] Community health workers and care teams provide outreach to help patients reestablish care routines, navigate benefits programs, and access behavioral health services. While CCM cannot fully resolve systemic housing and infrastructure challenges, these support services help mitigate barriers to care and promote continuity of health services for displaced and vulnerable residents.

[HEADING] c. Any other significant needs that impact health status or needs for primary care services.

[TEXT] Provider Shortages

[TEXT] According to the University of Hawai'i (2024), Maui County has an estimated shortage of 174 physicians overall, including 40.5 FTEs in primary care. Local adjustments to the national benchmark yield an average ratio of about 1,300 residents per primary care FTE. At this ratio, Maui's shortage of 40.5 FTEs translates to nearly 53,000 residents affected by limited access to care.

[TEXT] The healthcare provider shortage severely strains capacity, limiting timely access to care and places added pressure on existing resources. CCM faces challenges in offering competitive wages and benefits compared to the local and national markets, particularly when Hawaii's high cost of living is factored in.

[TEXT] In Hawai'i, pediatricians and family medicine physicians earn among the lowest annual mean wages in the nation, while obstetricians and gynecologists rank among the highest. A local physician reported in The Maui News (2021) that limited enrollment capacity at the John A. Burns School of Medicine and a lack of residency opportunities hinder the development of a homegrown workforce. More than 70 percent of medical students graduate with an average educational debt of $212,341 (American Medical Association, 2023). In 2024, a year after the

[TEXT] 3. Describe any recent or potential changes in the local health care landscape and how those changes may affect the needs of the target population.

[TEXT] Maui's health care landscape is changing as federal policy shifts affect insurance coverage, reimbursement rates, and workforce funding. Adjustments to Medicaid eligibility, Title X family planning funds, and federal workforce programs could reduce access to affordable care, particularly for low-income and uninsured residents who already face geographic and financial barriers. Any reduction in these supports may increase reliance on safety-net providers like CCM, heightening demand for primary care, behavioral health, and enabling services across the island.

[TEXT] As financial and system pressures grow, CCM's community health workers and care teams must take a more proactive role in outreach to keep patients engaged and prevent gaps in care. Many patients now experience greater stress related to economic instability and access barriers, arriving with higher emotional distress and requiring additional support and care coordination. These challenges make health education and early intervention critical to prevent chronic conditions from worsening, which can raise patient costs and further strain limited island health resources.

[TEXT] Access to care on Maui is divided between Kaiser Permanente members, who receive services through Kaiser's closed network, and non-Kaiser patients who rely mainly on Maui Medical Group, CCM, or independent practices. In 2023, the closure of a private obstetrics practice created a crisis for pregnant women on Maui, leaving CCM as the only obstetrics provider for those not insured by Kaiser and increasing the number of commercially insured patients we serve. In Hawai'i, reimbursement rates for deliveries are about half the national average, and commercial rates are even lower. Additionally, to maintain access for high-risk pregnancies, CCM covers the cost of flying in a maternal-fetal medicine specialist and a sonographer from Honolulu to provide services that would otherwise be unavailable on the island. Strained resources resulting from changes in the healthcare landscape may challenge our capacity to deliver essential services locally, particularly for patients who cannot afford to travel off-island for care.

[HEADING] 4. Describe how you determined the number of:

[TEXT] a. Unduplicated patients that you project to serve in the assessment period. If your projection is different than the Patient Target advertised in the SAAT, explain why.

[TEXT] The projected number of unduplicated patients for the assessment period was determined using the patient target listed in the Service Area Announcement Table (SAAT), which aligns closely with CCM's 2024 UDS-reported patient total. This projection reflects a realistic expectation to sustain current service levels and meet the established target. Given existing provider shortages and periodic clinical vacancies, CCM elected not to project an increase beyond the SAAT target to ensure projections remain achievable within current staffing capacity while maintaining access and quality of care.

[HEADING] b. Patients that you project to serve for each service type that is required for the service area (listed in the Service Type column of the SAAT).

[TEXT] CCM projected the number of patients for each required service type based on 2024 UDS data ratios, reflecting expected continuity in service utilization patterns across programs. The projections include 9,231 medical patients, 3,705 dental patients, 621 mental health patients, 254 substance use patients, and 2,053 enabling services patients. While most service categories remain consistent with prior utilization trends, enabling services are projected to increase proportionally to account for anticipated growth in patient needs related to loss of government benefits and greater demand for assistance with insurance navigation, transportation, and access to community resources.

[HEADING] 5 . Describe how you will:

[HEADING] a. Conduct and update your needs assessment.

[TEXT] CCM maintains a continuous and structured process for assessing community needs and aligning services to meet those needs. The health center conducts a comprehensive Community Health Needs Assessment (CHNA) every three years, supplemented by annual updates that inform program planning, resource allocation, and strategic priorities.

[TEXT] The assessment incorporates both quantitative and qualitative data. Quantitative sources include HRSA UDS data, Epic data and registry reports, social determinants of health screenings, community-level data from the Hawai'i Department of Health, University of Hawaii Manoa data reports, U.S. Census, and GeoCare Navigator as well as other community-based needs assessment data reports. Qualitative insights are gathered through patient and community listening sessions, school-based focus groups, key-informant interviews with partner agencies, and feedback from CHWs who engage directly with underserved populations. Findings are then reviewed by the Programs, Quality, and Finance teams to identify emerging trends in access, disparities, and utilization then presented to the Board of Directors for review.

[HEADING] b. Regularly update your Scope of Project in response to the needs for additional services.

[TEXT] In addition to the CHNA, CCM regularly reviews and updates its Scope of Project to ensure it reflects the evolving needs of the community. Scope changes are considered when new services or sites are required, when utilization data indicate consistent access barriers, or when grant awards and emergencies drive expansion. The process includes a detailed needs justification analysis covering demand, equity impact, workforce readiness, and financial feasibility, followed by operational and compliance review. Proposed updates are presented to the Board of Directors for approval prior to submission to HRSA. After implementation, service and financial outcomes are reviewed to confirm alignment with the projected goals.

[HEADING] c. Use patient and community input to inform and improve your service delivery.

[TEXT] Feedback collected through surveys, the health center's website comment section, and patient communication messages sent after visits. The Quality team reviews all comments, compliments, and complaints to identify patterns and address individual concerns. Summaries of this feedback are discussed in Quality meetings, where opportunities for improvement are evaluated and tracked. When appropriate, improvement processes such as Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) cycles are implemented. Significant trends or issues are reported to the Board of Directors for review

[TEXT] 1. Describe how the proposed service delivery sites on Form 5B: Service Sites will support access to your services (consistent with Form 5A: Services Provided) and minimize barriers within the proposed service area, including:

[TEXT] a. Where your service delivery sites are located, compared to where the target population lives and works.

[TEXT] CCM sites are accessible by foot in some locations, private vehicles, and public transportation. CCM's main site in Wailuku, designated by HRSA as an urban area, is located in Central Maui near government offices, major public schools, and local businesses (HRSA, 2025). The Wailuku satellite, about 10 minutes from the main site, operates within Maui's main homeless resource center.

[TEXT] CCM's West Maui satellite serves one of the island's most rural regions, located about 45 minutes from Central Maui and accessible by a single main road. This satellite site reduces drive time or public transportation commute for patients residing in West Maui. The original West Maui satellite was destroyed in the 2023 Maui Wildfires. Previously located at the Na Hale o Wainee Homeless Resource Center, CCM relocated this satellite site to Kahana, one of the few commercial properties available after the disaster. Residents displaced by the wildfire are an additional 10 to 15 minutes further from CCM's previous West Maui satellite, or they now access care at our main location if they relocated to other parts of the island.

[TEXT] CCM has expanded access to care by establishing school-based health centers at Kihei Elementary, Lokelani Intermediate, and Maui High School. Kīhei is approximately a 20- to 30- minute drive from CCM's Wailuku site in central Maui, where many parents also work, and up to 45 minutes from Wailea, where some are employed in the hotel industry. The distance, combined with parents' work schedules, make it difficult for children to access timely care. Before the opening of Kulanihakoi High School, Maui High served as the primary public high school for Kihei students. For non-Kaiser patients, access to pediatric care in Kihei was previously very limited.

[HEADING] a. How you will address geographic barriers, location of sites, and hours of operation.

[HEADING] Transportation

[TEXT] To address geographic barriers to care, CCM provides comprehensive transportation coordination and support for patients. Patient transportation needs vary for medical appointments at CCM locations, with specialist providers outside of CCM, and prescription pick-up. Some specialists are only located on the island of Oahu, and patients have to take a flight and taxi to their appointment.

[TEXT] The referral specialists and CHWs assist with transportation coordination for all medical needs, including outer-island travel. CCM staff coordinate with insurance payers for the patient's transportation benefit. CHWs educate patients on how to utilize their insurance transportation benefits independently. Patients without insurance or denied insurance-coordinated transportation services are given rides through CCM's facility-paid rideshare contract. Roundtrip is a rideshare company that CCM contracts with to provide Uber or Lyft rides for ambulatory patients to get to medical appointments or to pick up their prescriptions. CHWs also coordinate transportation through Maui Economic Opportunity where more assistance is available for individuals with disabilities.

[HEADING] Street Medicine

[TEXT] The Street Medicine Program (SM) delivers healthcare directly to individuals experiencing significant social and economic challenges, meeting them where they live. Many unsheltered individuals remain in their encampments due to transportation limitations or the need to safeguard their belongings. A medical provider and community health worker conduct outreach twice per week across the island, reducing obstacles to consistent care.

[HEADING] Emergency Coverage

[TEXT] CCM maintains a policy to ensure patient access to urgent/emergent after-hours medical advice and assistance. All medical providers must rotate on-call responsibilities during the hours when the health center is closed, including overnight, on weekends, and during holidays. Patients are provided the clinic phone number and instructions in multiple languages about how to access a provider after hours upon intake. This information is also made available on CCM's website. The following services are in place for after-hours coverage:

[TEXT] · Clarus Care, Inc. 24-hour call coverage for HIPAA compliant, continuous daytime and after-hours patient communication. After-hours, patients accessing the CCM phone system are redirected to the Clarus call center, where the call is answered and recorded. Each department's on-call provider receives notification by Clarus of the call and can respond via voicemail or text-to-speech for appointment inquiries but must respond via direct phone call to patients seeking clinical advice or critical result notifications. Providers are responsible for entering information into patients' records.

[TEXT] · Physician coverage agreement with Maui Medical Group that provides continuous general medical hospital admitting, inpatient, and assigned call coverage services at

[TEXT] a. How all age groups will have access to all required services and any additional services that are identified in your needs assessment.

[TEXT] CCM ensures that all required primary care services are available and accessible to patients of all ages-infants, children, adolescents, adults, and older adults-through its integrated service delivery system. Comprehensive services are provided at main clinic sites, satellite clinics, school-based health centers, and through mobile and outreach teams. Patients are assigned to a designated primary care provider to support continuity of care and may access same-day appointments for acute needs.

[TEXT] General Primary Medical Care Family Medicine, Internal Medicine, Pediatrics, and OB/GYN departments provide comprehensive primary care, preventive screenings, and management of chronic and acute conditions. Services include physical exams, immunizations, lab and imaging diagnostics, medication management, and referrals to specialty care.

[TEXT] Women's and Maternal Health Services

[TEXT] Women of reproductive age receive comprehensive OB/GYN services, including prenatal, intrapartum, and postpartum care, preventive screenings including mammogram referrals, family planning, and infertility support. Maternal Fetal Medicine consultations and advanced imaging are available through contracted specialists to ensure continuity of perinatal care.

[HEADING] Child and Adolescent Services

[TEXT] Pediatric and school-based sites provide EPSDT visits, immunizations, developmental and behavioral screenings, health education, and acute and chronic care management. Adolescents have access to confidential family planning and behavioral health counseling consistent with Hawaii state law.

[TEXT] Adult and Geriatric Services

[TEXT] Adult and internal medicine providers focus on chronic disease prevention and management (e.g., diabetes, hypertension, asthma, HIV/AIDS), preventive screenings, and acute care. Patients receive medication review, immunizations, and coordination with specialty providers to support complex health needs.

[HEADING] Integrated and Enabling Services

[TEXT] Patients of all ages have access to integrated behavioral health, substance use disorder services, oral health, pharmacy, and nutrition therapy. Enabling services include eligibility and insurance assistance, case management, transportation support, interpretation, and outreach. Health education and preventive counseling are embedded into all care settings. Services are offered from multiple health center sites to ensure access and coordination for patients of all ages.

[HEADING] Access and Continuity

[TEXT] CCM maintains extended and same-day appointments, after-hours call coverage, and telehealth access to minimize barriers. Services are available regardless of insurance status or ability to pay, supported by CCM's sliding fee discount program.

[TEXT] b. Which required services on Form 5A: Services Provided you will not provide in-person at all service delivery sites and how you will make those services accessible to all patients.

[TEXT] Certain required services listed on Form 5A are not provided in-person at every delivery site due to variations in space, equipment, and staffing (refer to the table below: Sites and Services). These services remain fully accessible to all patients through formal contracts, referral arrangements, and coordinated scheduling by care teams.

[TEXT] Diagnostic Laboratory Services

[TEXT] CLIA-waived laboratory tests and screenings are performed on-site by CCM clinical staff at all primary care locations. CLIA non-waived laboratory testing is provided under contract with Clinical Laboratories of Hawaii, LLP (CLH). CCM pays for tests included on its formulary, while CLH bills directly for off-formulary services and offers discounted rates for uninsured or underinsured patients. Laboratory services are available on-site at CCM's main clinic, with results transmitted electronically into the patient's electronic health record to ensure continuity of care.

[TEXT] Diagnostic Radiology Services

[TEXT] Advanced diagnostic radiology, including obstetrical ultrasounds, fetal biophysical profiles, and Doppler studies, is provided by CCM's credentialed physician and radiology technician in only two locations. Additional diagnostic and screening radiology services are available through a formal contract with Maui Medical Group, Inc. (MMG). CCM pays MMG for formulary services, and MMG bills for non-formulary services. All images and reports are transmitted

[HEADING] Accessibility and Coordination

[TEXT] For all services provided in specific CCM sites or through contracts or referrals, CCM staff assist patients with scheduling, referral tracking, and transportation coordination as needed. Results and reports are integrated into the electronic health record and reviewed by the patient's primary care provider to maintain seamless, in-scope access across all locations. Referral coordinators track appointment completion and ensure that all reports and results are returned to the primary provider for follow-up.

[TEXT] c. How you will provide in-scope patient-centered chronic disease prevention and management, preventive health services and education, cancer screening, nutrition, mental health, and patient support services.

[TEXT] CCM provides in-scope required and additional services directly or through formal written agreements as documented on Form 5A: Services Provided.

[TEXT] Patient-Centered Chronic Disease Prevention and Management

[TEXT] CCM provides comprehensive, team-based primary care that integrates prevention, early detection, and chronic disease management across all age groups. Services are delivered by Medical Doctors and Nurse Practitioners that are assigned to a patient panel. Patients are scheduled with their designated primary care provider for most of their visits, but CCM allows patients to see the first available provider in a more acute situation. [TEXT] includes one Nurse and one Medical Assistant; where provider support staff may rotate between part-time providers.

[TEXT] Family Medicine, Internal Medicine, Pediatrics, and OB/GYN providers deliver ongoing preventive and chronic care for hypertension, diabetes, asthma, cardiovascular disease, and infectious diseases such as HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, and hepatitis. Providers use population health tools and daily huddle reports to identify care gaps and track patients with uncontrolled conditions. Nurse visits, same-day access, and patient self-management plans reinforce follow- up and disease control. Patients with elevated blood pressure or A1C are enrolled in monitoring programs, provided home blood pressure devices, and receive coaching through the care team and community health workers (CHWs).

[TEXT] Quality Coordinators track when patients are due for chronic disease or preventive visits and conduct phone outreach to schedule appointments, ensuring timely follow-up and continuity of care.

[HEADING] Preventive Health Services and Education

[TEXT] All patients receive age-appropriate physical exams, immunizations, and screenings for hypertension, cholesterol, blood sugar, vision, hearing, depression, and sexually transmitted infections, and are done in-house. Specialty screenings such as mammography are coordinated through contracted partners. Providers follow evidence-based clinical guidelines to guide screening, counseling, and prevention.

[TEXT] Care plans emphasize patient engagement, self-management goals, and culturally appropriate education tailored to each patient's needs. Health education is embedded into all primary care visits, emphasizing lifestyle modification, medication adherence, and preventive practices. Additional nursing visits are scheduled for patients who require more frequent monitoring, follow-up, or medication support. Group education sessions are offered for diabetes, hypertension, pregnancy, and parenting.

[HEADING] Cancer Screening

[TEXT] CCM provides routine cancer screenings and referrals according to national clinical guidelines. Pap tests and mammogram referrals are provided through OB/GYN, while colorectal cancer screening is conducted through stool testing or referral for colonoscopy. CCM collaborates with Maui Health Foundation to provide free screening and diagnostic mammography services for uninsured patients.

[HEADING] Nutrition Services

[TEXT] A Licensed Registered Dietitian provides medical nutrition therapy, education, and counseling for patients diagnosed with hypertension, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, kidney and liver disease. Nutrition care is coordinated with primary care and behavioral health teams to support disease prevention and self-management.

[TEXT] Mental Health and Substance Use Services

[TEXT] Integrated Behavioral Health services are co-located within primary care. Licensed Clinical Social Workers, and Psychiatrists provide screening, assessment, and evidence-based treatment for depression, anxiety, and other mental health conditions. CCM offers Medication-Assisted

[HEADING] d. How you will support continuity, clinical effectiveness, and patient-centered care coordination.

[TEXT] CCM ensures continuity, clinical effectiveness, and patient-centered care coordination through a data-driven approach guided by evidence and performance metrics. A monthly Quality, Clinical Operations, and Practice meeting brings together interdisciplinary teams including leadership, clinical, quality, and enabling services staff to review performance and align improvement efforts. Quality metrics tied to UDS and PCMH standards are tracked and presented through dashboards. The team reviews workflows and evaluates both process and outcome measures to identify opportunities for improvement and ensure consistent, high-quality care delivery.

[TEXT] In addition, the health center's Data Analyst develops and presents dashboards that monitor appointment availability, patient utilization, and service trends to identify and address access gaps. Quality Coordinators use this data to conduct targeted outreach, supporting proactive management of chronic and preventive care needs and ensuring patients are scheduled into the earliest available appointments for timely care.

[TEXT] CCM utilizes Epic as its electronic health record system (EHR), the same EHR as the island's main hospital which allows for data sharing through a formal agreement. CCM's Epic optimization team is responsible for training, monitoring, and supporting staff in EHR documentation. The team develops and distributes tip sheets to reinforce proper documentation practices and ensure accuracy across departments. By standardizing workflows and providing ongoing technical support, the team ensures that data is captured consistently and correctly, improving both clinical effectiveness and reporting integrity.

[TEXT] Our patient-centered coordination includes warm handoffs between departments, referral tracking and coordination, hospital discharge follow-ups, and case management that supports patient goals and social needs. During primary care visits, CCM staff assess patients for additional needs, including social barriers to care, behavioral health, substance use, nutrition, and dental concerns. Warm handoffs are made during or after the visit to connect patients directly with the appropriate referral provider.

[TEXT] CCM's Health Information Technology (HIT) and Referrals teams strengthens care coordination by managing provider referrals and assisting patients with scheduling appointments for specialty or ancillary services. This may also include coordinating patient benefits such as arranging transportation or travel. The team also facilitates the exchange of health records across systems,

[TEXT] giving providers timely, accurate information for effective, integrated clinical decision-making. Providers receive notifications of incoming electronic records directly in their Epic inbox.

[TEXT] CCM offers dedicated hospital follow-up appointments so patients are seen in a timely manner after discharge. The hospital's case manager calls CCM to schedule the patient's appointment or when CCM receives discharge records, HIT will reach out to the patient to schedule an appointment if one is not already scheduled. The Street Medicine program also coordinates hospital follow-ups for unsheltered individuals in partnership with the respite shelter.

[TEXT] Each patient's primary care team includes a primary care provider, a registered nurse, and a medical assistant. Nurses provide case management as needed, which includes creating individualized care plans with measurable goals, offering additional visits for health education and medication management, and monitoring progress to adjust plans as appropriate. The OB/GYN department also has a dedicated nurse case manager for high-risk pregnancies who coordinates additional services and resources to support maternal and fetal health.

[TEXT] Community Health Workers (CHWs) help patients carry out their care plans by addressing practical and social needs that affect access to care. They coordinate transportation, connect patients to food and housing resources, and enroll patients for health insurance coverage. CHWs also help patients with health insurance coverage changes, such as changing PCPs or renewing their eligibility.

[TEXT] The health center provides three language services to assist patients who do not speak English; in-person medical interpretation, Language Line, and VOYCE services. The health center certifies bi-lingual staff as Certified Medical Interpreters. We have interpreters for Ilocano, Tagalog, Spanish, Kosraean, Chuukese, and Marshallese. Medical interpreters work as registered nurses, medical assistants, and community health workers throughout the health center. Interpretation is provided from registration, during the patient visit, and during follow-up and care plan management.

[TEXT] Language Line provides on-demand interpreter services over the phone for over 240 languages. The front desk, eligibility specialist offices, and some medical exam rooms are equipped with double receiver phones for the patient, interpreter, and CCM staff member to communicate. VOYCE is a video interpretation service that provides on-demand interpreters for over 240 languages. The health center has iPads in different areas of the health center to access the VOYCE application. CHWs also have access to Language Line and VOYCE services when assisting patients outside the health center at specialist or social service resource appointments.

[TEXT] Case management services described in 2d (previous answer).

[TEXT] CHWs also collaborate with the health center's registered dietitian to coordinate culturally relevant health and nutrition education. Monthly group sessions provide patients with practical guidance on topics such as reading food labels, maintaining a balanced diet, portion control, and planning healthy meals on a budget. CHWs also provide one-on-one health education during home visits, tailoring topics in collaboration with the care team to address each patient's specific needs and health goals.

[TEXT] CCM partners with the Maui Food Bank to distribute senior food boxes. CHWs assist patients with enrollment, collect the boxes each month, and coordinate either on-site pickup or home delivery to ensure seniors receive their food regularly. CCM partners with Project Vision that offers on-site SNAP enrollment assistance for patients one day each week. On other days, CHWs help patients complete applications and provide follow-up support. The University of Hawai'i Maui College supplies fresh produce from its aquaponics program to support CCM's food access efforts. CHWs pick up and distribute the produce weekly to patients who participate in health education classes, as well as to those experiencing food insecurity.

[TEXT] To address housing insecurity, CHWs assist patients in identifying housing programs for which they may qualify and provide hands-on support with completing applications. The Street Medicine team delivers care directly to unsheltered patients in the community, ensuring access to essential medical services regardless of housing status. Care plans are tailored to each patient's living situation, emphasizing health maintenance, medication access, and safety while working toward stable housing.

[TEXT] f. How your services will account for patient-centered care that is tailored to the individual, empowers them to make informed decisions about their health and to actively participate in their care, and supports the development of a comprehensive care plan to support patients in meeting their health goals.

[TEXT] CCM takes a trauma-informed and culturally responsive approach that prioritizes trust, safety, and respect for each patient's background and readiness to engage in care. Providers and care team members meet patients where they are, offering guidance in a supportive, nonjudgmental way. Care is delivered with cultural humility and relevance. Staff avoid lecturing on foods or practices that are unfamiliar to a patient's culture and instead focus on realistic, sustainable recommendations that align with their traditions and preferences. Interpretation is provided to ensure full understanding, and CHWs share cultural insights and education with staff to strengthen awareness and sensitivity across the care team. This approach empowers patients to make informed decisions and set achievable goals within the context of their own values and daily lives.

[TEXT] g. How the additional services you provide will address any other unique needs that impact health status.

[TEXT] While CCM already offers a comprehensive range of services, we add new ones only when they can be sustained without overextending resources. The School-Based Health Center program is a key extension of our outreach and care coordination efforts, allowing us to identify and address student health needs directly on campus. The health center provides primary care, behavioral

In addition, our team provides classroom-based health education on topics that are not typically covered in school, such as how to communicate with a doctor, understand medications, and take an active role in one's own health. By bringing care and education to schools, we reduce barriers for families, such as parents needing to leave work, and help students become active stewards of their health through early awareness and consistent access to care.

[TEXT] 3. Describe how you will expand access to additional services such as nutrition counseling and wellness promotion in response to your needs assessment.

[TEXT] CCM regularly evaluates patient data, community feedback, and population health trends to identify service gaps and emerging needs. In collaboration with care teams, patients who may benefit from additional programs or health education sessions are identified and connected to appropriate services. To ensure access for diverse populations, CCM hires culture- and language- specific CHWs, such as a Spanish-speaking CHW, to effectively engage patients and communities that may face linguistic or cultural barriers. These services are integrated into primary care visits, group education sessions, and community outreach events. When needs increase in specific populations, CCM adjusts staffing, workflows, and community partnerships to expand access, such as offering additional nutrition education sessions or wellness activities at schools and other community sites.

[TEXT] 4. Describe how you will keep providing the services that HRSA has previously supported through a supplemental award. Address all supplements awarded since FY 2023. If you have questions about the supplemental services provided in your service area, contact us using the BPHC Contact Form. In your narrative, include: a. What level of services you currently provide and how you will continue to provide, change, or expand these services to meet the needs you identified in your needs assessment.

[TEXT] CCM operates three School-Based Health Centers at Kihei Elementary, Lokelani Intermediate, and Maui High School. Services include pediatric primary care, immunizations, sports physicals, behavioral health support, and health education. Each site currently serves an average of three to six patients per day. Kihei Elementary has a medical provider on site one to two days per week, Maui High operates two days per week, and Lokelani students receive medical care at the Kihei Elementary site. Behavioral health CHWs rotate among all campuses to provide outreach and support. As the program grows, CCM continues to build trust and strong relationships within each school community. As visit volume increases and the program becomes more sustainable, the health center plans to expand on-site services by adding an LCSW to provide consistent, advanced behavioral health support and by increasing provider availability at each campus.

[TEXT] 5 . Describe the following aspects of your sliding fee discount program policies: a. How you assess all patients for sliding fee discount eligibility based only on income and family size. See income definition in Chapter 9: Sliding Fee Discount Program of the Compliance Manual.

[TEXT] CCM assesses all patients for Sliding Fee Discount eligibility based solely on income and family size. Patients are informed of the Sliding Fee Discount Program (SFDP) during registration and annually thereafter. Income is a family's gross income reported for federal income tax purposes including gross wages, social security/disability benefits, child support, retirement benefits, unemployment and other public assistance. The applicant and the number of individuals who qualify as an IRS dependent of the applicant determine the family size. This includes the applicant, spouse, dependent children and any other individual that qualifies as a personal exemption for tax reporting purposes. The Organization will use the IRS definition of a dependent to determine family size, even if the applicant does not a file tax return.

[TEXT] The eligibility determination process is conducted in an efficient, respectful, and culturally appropriate manner to assure that administrative operating procedures for such determinations do not themselves present a barrier to care.

[TEXT] . On the first visit for new patients, and every year thereafter, the patient completes the Intake Form in which patients verbally confirm income and family size. Income and family size are then entered into the billing system to assign the appropriate sliding fee category.

[TEXT] · In order to qualify for sliding fee scale discounts under the SFDP, the patient must complete a Sliding Fee Discount Application and provide appropriate proof of income documentation. Acceptable documentation includes one of the following:

[TEXT] Current pay stub for three months (calculate the average)

[TEXT] o Bank statement showing monthly income

[TEXT] Current tax return

[TEXT] :unselected: ○ Confirmation letter from Department of Human Services (welfare recipient)

[TEXT] :unselected: Unemployment compensation stub

[TEXT] :unselected: ○ Signed Self-Attestation Form (if unable to collect any of the above)

[TEXT] If proof of income is not available on the first visit, the patient will be provided a sliding fee scale discount based on the information contained in the Intake Form. Patients are required to bring proof of income and submit a completed Sliding Fee Discount Program Application at the next visit.

[TEXT] SFDS coverage is available for 1 year from the date of application. All patients regardless of insurance status will be assessed for household size and income. b. How you adjust patient charges based on the ability to pay (consistent with Attachment 10: Sliding Fee Discount Schedule).

[TEXT] CCM's Fee Waiver Policy authorizes reductions or waivers of fees under specific, documented hardship circumstances such as loss of employment, medical emergencies, or catastrophic life events. Other situations that demonstrate that the patient would be unable to pay medical bills and still be able to pay for other basic necessary expenses are also considered. CCM staff

[TEXT] c. Whether you have a nominal charge for patients with incomes at or below 100% of the Federal Poverty Guidelines (FPG). If so, describe how the amount is nominal from the perspective of the patient and would not reflect the actual cost of the service being provided.

[TEXT] Locally prevailing rates or charges, Medicaid cost reports, UDS reports, and other relevant sources are used to inform the cost of services on CCM's fee schedule. CCM applies a flat, nominal charge for patients with incomes at or below 100% of the FPG that does not reflect the actual cost of the service being provided.

[TEXT] The setting of the nominal charge is based on input from our Patient Board Members, Patient Satisfaction Surveys, and a review of co-pays and co-insurance associated with Medicare and Medicaid Plans.

[TEXT] d. How you evaluate your sliding fee discount program to ensure that it reduces financial barriers to care.

[TEXT] CCM conducts regular reviews of:

[TEXT] · Self-pay patient utilization trends, including visit volumes and service types accessed by patients eligible for sliding fee discounts, to assess whether patients are using services proportionate to community need.

[TEXT] · Collection rates and bad debt reports, to determine whether fees remain affordable and payment expectations are realistic for low-income patients.

[TEXT] · Patient feedback and satisfaction surveys, which include questions on affordability and access, to identify perceived or experienced barriers related to cost.

[TEXT] · Annual analysis of the Sliding Fee Discount Schedule, comparing discount classes, nominal charges, and household income documentation practices to current Federal Poverty Guidelines.

[HEADING] 6. Describe how you provide care that:

[HEADING] a. Engages patients to participate in their care and maximize their experience of their care.

[TEXT] CCM engages patients in their care by fostering a supportive environment where patients are active partners in decision-making. Providers use motivational interviewing, shared goal setting, and teach-back methods to ensure understanding and encourage participation. Staff use a trauma- informed and culturally responsive approach, meeting patients where they are and tailoring information to their readiness and cultural background. CHWs and nurses reinforce education through follow-up calls, home visits, and group sessions to help patients apply what they learn in daily life. Patient feedback is collected through satisfaction surveys and informal input, which is reviewed by the Quality Team to identify opportunities for improvement and enhance the overall care experience.

[HEADING] b. Involves families and caregivers, as appropriate.

[TEXT] Grant Number: 6 H80CS00722-24-07

[TEXT] CCM involves families and caregivers as active participants in the patient's care when appropriate and with patient consent. Care teams encourage family involvement during visits, especially for pediatric, prenatal, geriatric, and chronic disease management patients. Education and care plans are shared in clear, accessible language, with interpreters available to ensure full understanding. CHWs encourage patients to identify their personal support systems and define what effective support looks like for them, including how to communicate their needs for the best outcomes. CHWs also engage caregivers outside of visits to reinforce care instructions, assist with appointment coordination, and connect families to supportive resources such as nutrition, housing, or behavioral health services. Families are also welcome to attend group health education sessions with the patient. This approach builds a strong network around each patient, supporting adherence to care plans and better health outcomes.

[HEADING] c. Aligns with the needs of the underserved populations in the area.

[TEXT] CCM designs its services to address the unique barriers and circumstances of the Maui community. The island's high cost of living means many individuals and families experience financial hardship, with adults often working multiple jobs and having to prioritize basic needs, leaving limited resources for healthcare. CCM offers extended clinic hours to accommodate patients who cannot take time off work, ensuring that care remains accessible and flexible for all members of the community. Multiple service sites, including school-based health centers, give students convenient access to care while reducing the need for parents to miss work. Many patients may lack the time or ability to schedule their own appointments. CCM's Quality team conducts targeted outreach to schedule patients for needed services to prevent delays in care.

[TEXT] We recognize that many patients use their limited resources just to reach an appointment, and that each visit may be our only opportunity to address their needs. For this reason, CCM provides comprehensive assessments and same-day warm handoffs to connect patients with the appropriate services. Comprehensive primary care services include integrated behavioral health support, including nutrition and substance use counseling, to care for the whole person and address the underlying factors that affect overall health and wellness. These services are offered in one location, making care convenient and accessible. CCM provides Street Medicine services to reach unsheltered patients directly where they are. Our outreach efforts ensure that we connect with patients who face barriers to accessing care and may not otherwise reach the health center. CHWs follow up after visits to offer resources, reinforce care plans, and keep patients engaged in their ongoing care. Our sliding fee scale and collection policies ensure patients can receive affordable care, and are not turned away for inability to pay.

[TEXT] 7. Describe your process to ensure continuity of care for patients. Include: a. Communication tools, referral processes, and electronic exchange of patient health

[TEXT] records. Answered in 2d.

[TEXT] b. Hospital admitting privileges.

[TEXT] CCM Medical Doctors are credentialed and privileged at the hospital for direct admission. For example, a patient at the health center needing hospital inpatient care. In that case, the clinical care team will arrange for emergency transportation or have a family member drive the patient to

[TEXT] the hospital, depending on the severity of the patient's illness. A privileged provider will fill out the Direct Admission Form from Maui Memorial Medical Center (MMMC) and fax it to the appropriate unit. The provider will also call the hospital inpatient unit to report on the patient. MMMC staff will complete hospital admission upon the patient's arrival.

[HEADING] c. Receipt, follow-up, and recording of medical information from referral sources.

[TEXT] Referral sources may include other medical providers or a patient's medical insurance payer. Medical information is securely transmitted through fax, secure email, or directly through Epic and followed-up with a phone call. Staff receiving patient information should communicate information internally directly via the electronic health record, or transfer documentation to HIT to scan into the patient's electronic health record for provider review.

[TEXT] Specialty care appointments referred by CCM Primary Care Providers are tracked by the Data Interoperability Team, which includes Health Information Technology (HIT) and Referrals staff, to ensure patients complete their consultations. The HIT department receives visit reports via the electronic health record, secure file sharing, or fax from specialists and uploads them into the patient's chart in Epic. A dashboard in Epic tracks which patients have completed or not completed their specialty appointments. HIT verifies that records are received for all completed visits and contacts the specialist's office if documentation is missing. For patients who did not complete their appointment, HIT notifies the Referrals Department to follow-up and get patients scheduled or rescheduled.

[TEXT] After providers review the patient's visit documentation, the provider will call to provide the patient with their results or ask the care team to schedule a follow-up visit with the patient if needed.

[HEADING] d. Follow-up for patients who are hospitalized or visit a hospital's emergency department.

[TEXT] CCM contracts with Maui Medical Group and Hawaii Permanente Group to provide continuous call coverage for general medicine, Ob/Gyn, and pediatric hospital inpatient services, and assigned call coverage at MMMC, respectively, for our patients. Hospital patients without a primary care provider and health insurance are also directed to call for an appointment at CCM prior to discharge. If the patient is unable to call, the Case Manager assigned to the patient at the hospital will work directly with CCM to obtain a hospital follow-up appointment.

[TEXT] When the patient is discharged, the HIT department is alerted via daily fax from MMMC or automatically sent electronic health records through Epic if the patient consents. HIT staff will alert the primary care team through their Epic inbox when the patient's appointment is scheduled and records are ready for review.

[TEXT] If the patient is not scheduled within seven days of discharge from the hospital, HIT staff will call the patient to schedule an appointment. If the patient misses their hospital follow-up appointment, the provider's care team will contact the patient to reschedule an appointment. Two phone calls are made within two days. If the patient cannot be contacted a certified letter is sent to the patient's address. Instances that the provider determines that an emergency or urgent situation exists, law enforcement is contacted to locate the patient; and all attempted and actual contacts by phone and letter are documented in EHR.

[HEADING] COLLABORATION

[HEADING] 1. Describe how you collaborate with community partners to increase awareness of and address the community's health and health-related needs.

[TEXT] CCM's Community Engagement Department and Director of Community Partnerships participate in community health fairs and events hosted by partner organizations to strengthen relationships, enhance referral networks, and maintain direct communication channels while promoting awareness of CCM's services and programs. A direct communication channel means that when someone calls, a person answers rather than an automated menu, allowing for timely and personal responses to community needs.

[TEXT] For example, hospital case workers contact CCM's Street Medicine program when unsheltered patients are being discharged and need follow-up medical care while staying at the Ka Hale A Ke Ola respite shelter. Once an appointment is scheduled, CCM staff confirm with the Ka Hale A Ke Ola case manager to coordinate on-site care. When the referral process needs refinement, CCM's Programs Director, the Executive Director at Ka Hale A Ke Ola, and the hospital's case manager supervisor meet to identify opportunities for improvement and strengthen coordination. This approach improves access to care and helps address social determinants of health.

[TEXT] Partnerships like these often take the form of referral systems, shared resources, or data exchange to stay informed about emerging community priorities. Maui's nonprofit community relies heavily on collaboration and in-person networking to coordinate efforts, stretch limited resources, and prevent duplication of services that support shared goals. Awareness and education are further advanced through CCM's social media and cross-promotional efforts, which share public health messages, upcoming events, and community resources in coordination with partner organizations.

[TEXT] a. How the team will support the operation and oversight of your Health Center Program project, including accountability, policies, and risk management.

[TEXT] CCM's executive leadership team ensures the effective operation, oversight, and accountability of the Health Center Program project through structured systems, regular communication, and data-driven management. All executive leaders hold standing one-on-one meetings with their direct reports to ensure clear, two-way communication, allowing information and feedback to flow effectively from frontline staff to leadership and from leadership back to staff.

[TEXT] · The Chief Executive Officer (CEO) provides strategic and operational oversight by convening regular leadership and board meetings, reviewing financial and clinical performance reports, and ensuring that all departments operate within approved policies and federal, state, and local regulations. Leadership meetings are focused on strategic planning and organizational priorities to ensure management operates with shared goals, consistent accountability, and an aligned leadership approach centered on supporting teams, maintaining compliance, and advancing the health center's mission. The CEO coordinates board engagement activities (e.g., site visits to satellite sites or school-based health centers) that give members meaningful opportunities to learn about the health center's operations, programs, and community impact to strengthen their understanding and oversight of organizational performance.

[TEXT] · The Chief Financial Officer (CFO) manages fiscal accountability through internal controls, monthly financial reconciliations, and reporting to the CEO and Board Finance Committee. The CFO leads ongoing risk management by monitoring compliance with funding requirements, coordinating with auditors, and maintaining appropriate insurance coverage.

[TEXT] · The Chief Medical Officer (CMO) provides clinical leadership and oversight to ensure the delivery of safe, high-quality, and evidence-based care across all service sites. The CMO supervises medical providers and oversees credentialing, privileging, and peer review processes to ensure compliance with HRSA, FTCA, and clinical quality standards. In collaboration with the Clinical Operations and Quality teams, the CMO evaluates clinical outcomes, monitors risk indicators, and leads quality improvement initiatives focused on improving patient experience, access, and continuity of care. The CMO also leads the Clinical Quality Committee, ensuring provider engagement in reviewing performance data, developing corrective actions, and implementing best practices in alignment with UDS and HRSA benchmarks. The CMO collaborates with the Data

[TEXT] 3 . How you recruit, develop, engage, and retain the appropriate staffing mix of qualified providers to provide care to your target population.

[TEXT] CCM uses productivity data, patient demographics, and community health indicators to assess workforce needs and ensure an appropriate mix of providers across disciplines to meet patient demand and support equitable access to care. Recruitment emphasizes mission-driven candidates who demonstrate cultural competence and a commitment to serving underserved communities. Job postings are shared through CCM's website, social media, LinkedIn, and UKG human resources management platform. Candidate selection includes evaluation of clinical experience, alignment with CCM's culture and values, and ability to provide trauma-informed, team-based care.

[TEXT] CCM supports staff development through a rigorous and robust onboarding that includes cultural competency training, continuing medical education reimbursement, and participation in training offered by the Hawai'i Primary Care Association and other partners. Clinical department heads conduct regular one-on-one meetings with each provider to review performance, address challenges, and support professional growth. Engagement is fostered through open communication, interdisciplinary case reviews, and recognition of clinical achievements.

[TEXT] To promote retention, CCM maintains competitive compensation and benefits packages and creates advancement opportunities through leadership development and mentorship. CCM organizes recognition events such as Nurses Week and Caregivers Week, along with ongoing activities that build connection and appreciation across departments. Leadership also conducts regular C-suite walk-arounds and all-staff meetings where updates are shared directly from administration, creating opportunities for employees across service lines to connect and build relationships. CCM takes pride in maintaining welcoming staff spaces, including a dedicated
