[HEADING] 4. How your financial accounting and internal control systems, and policies:

[HEADING] a. Ensure effective control over all health center funds, property, and other assets.

[TEXT] Accounting policies and procedures consistent with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) are in place to ensure compliance with federal and state laws, regulations, contracts, and grant agreements. CCM's financial policies establish separation of duties across authorization, custody, record keeping, and reconciliation functions to provide a clear audit trail and maintain internal control.

[TEXT] CCM's Record Retention Policy defines minimum retention periods for all financial, personnel, and board records. Accounting records such as ledgers, checks, payroll reports, and vouchers are retained for six to eight years, while audit reports, legal documents, and board records are kept permanently. Records related to federal awards are maintained for at least three years after submission of the final expenditure report. The policy applies to both paper and electronic files and ensures that records remain accessible, auditable, and secure to support accountability and proper management of all assets.

[TEXT] All purchases require authorization for necessity, amount, and general ledger coding. Finance staff review financial policies regularly and participate in trainings as feasible. The CFO conducts final review of all payments to confirm proper coding and verify that all grant funds are expended in compliance with specific grant requirements and federal cost principles (45 CFR Part 75 Subpart E).

[TEXT] The inventory procedure involves using the Microix Requisition/PO workflow to purchase stock and accurately record goods upon receipt into a secure location. When items are needed, employees must submit a formal Inventory Shopping List request for approval before the Purchasing Specialist issues the goods, reducing the inventory balance and posting the corresponding expense. Regular physical counts (cycle counting/annual) and approved inventory adjustments are mandatory to ensure the system's stock levels and financial valuation remain accurate and controlled.

[TEXT] Procedure manuals are maintained to ensure segregation of duties, safeguard assets, maintain financial stability, and ensure compliance with federal regulations governing grant administration, cost principles, and financial reporting. These include processes for identifying federal awards received and expended, authorizations, obligations, budget-to-actual comparisons, property and procurement standards, and monitoring of financial performance.

[TEXT] b. Track the financial performance of the health center.

[TEXT] 33

[TEXT] Community Clinic of Maui, Inc. H80CS00722



========== PAGE 45 (from PDF footer) ==========

[TEXT] EHB Application Number: 243040

[TEXT] Grant Number: 6 H80CS00722-24-07

[TEXT] CCM tracks financial performance through regular reporting, analysis, and oversight to ensure fiscal accountability and long-term stability. Monthly financial statements, budget-to-actual variance reports, and grant expenditure summaries are prepared and reviewed by the CFO, CEO, and the Board Finance Committee. The full executive leadership team also reviews financial reports, as each member is responsible for the performance of their respective service lines, which collectively contribute to the organization's overall financial health.

[TEXT] Key performance indicators, including operating margin, days cash on hand, current ratio, accounts receivable aging, payer mix, and revenue per encounter, are monitored to evaluate financial health and identify trends. Corrective actions are developed for unfavorable variances, and annual independent audits provide external assurance of financial integrity and compliance with federal cost principles and grant requirements. The Finance Department also submits required Federal Financial Reports (FFR) and monitors expenditures against approved budgets to ensure that all federal funds are used appropriately.

[HEADING] c. Separate accounting for this award from other federal awards, including documentation of the receipt and expenditure of SAC funds.

[TEXT] Our financial accounting and internal control systems ensure complete separation and accurate documentation of the SAC award. This is achieved by assigning a unique General Ledger (GL) Fund Code exclusively to the SAC grant, preventing any commingling with other costs or funds. Expenditures are tracked and reconciled regularly (e.g., monthly) to monitor cash flow. The validity of these expenditures is verified using documentation generated by our payroll software which details the specific personnel. Our system ensures strict compliance with any mandated federal salary caps, with internal controls in place to track and prevent charging any salary costs exceeding the allowable limit to the SAC award.

[HEADING] d. Mitigate conflict of interest by board members, employees, and others when buying supplies, property, equipment, and services.

[TEXT] CCM mitigates conflicts of interest through its Board-approved Conflict of Interest Policy, which applies to all officers, directors, employees, and agents. The policy requires disclosure of any real or apparent conflicts and prohibits participation in procurement decisions where a conflict exists. Individuals involved in purchasing supplies, property, equipment, or services must disclose potential relationships and abstain from related decisions. Annual and ongoing disclosure forms are reviewed by the CEO and Board Chair to identify and resolve any conflicts. The policy also prohibits accepting gratuities or favors from vendors and outlines disciplinary action for violations.

[TEXT] 5. Your experience and plans for maintaining continuity of services and responding to urgent primary health care needs during natural or man-made disasters and public health emergencies. Your response should be consistent with all applicable Federal, state, and local laws and regulations.

[TEXT] Incident Command and Preparedness

[TEXT] CCM maintains a comprehensive Emergency Preparedness Policy, Plan, and Protocols to ensure continuity of operations and rapid response during natural disasters, public health emergencies,

[TEXT] and other critical incidents. These plans are reviewed and updated regularly to comply with federal, state, and local requirements and to ensure operational readiness across all service sites.

[TEXT] CCM uses the Incident Command System (ICS), aligned with FEMA's National Response Framework, to manage emergencies that impact normal operations. The Chief Operating Officer serves as the Incident Commander, supported by Command Staff responsible for communications, logistics, safety, operations, finance, and planning. CCM actively participates in the Hawaii Healthcare Emergency Management Coalition (HHEMC) and the Hawaii Primary Care Association (HPCA), engaging in meetings, training exercises, and coordinated response drills.

[HEADING] Emergency Communication Strategy

[TEXT] CCM's Emergency Communications Plan is reviewed and updated at least annually. The plan outlines internal and external communication channels to ensure timely information flow during emergencies. Multiple communication systems, including cellular and landline phones, internal messaging (SparkChat), Blackboard alerts, two-way radios, and HAM radio, provide redundancy. Staff receive semiannual emergency communications training, and equipment is tested monthly through HHEMC.

[TEXT] During emergencies, patient updates and coordination messages are issued through the electronic health record (EHR) communication system, CCM's website, official social media platforms and on-site signage. The health center coordinates closely with the County of Maui Emergency Management Agency, Maui Health System, and other community partners to align messaging, share situational updates, and support public information dissemination. Staff receive semiannual emergency communications training, and all communication systems are tested monthly through HHEMC drills.

[HEADING] Continuity of Operations and Recovery

[TEXT] CCM maintains a Continuity of Operations Plan (CCOP) that identifies essential functions and resource allocation to sustain critical services during disruptions. Site-specific recovery plans address facility access, staffing, and restoration of utilities and clinical operations.

[TEXT] Following an incident, recovery efforts include facility inspections, IT system assessments, and restoration of full clinical capacity as quickly as possible. Off-site data storage and EHR hosting is through Health Choice Network in order to protect patient data integrity and ensure uninterrupted access to clinical records. Leadership conducts after-action reviews to capture lessons learned and implement system improvements to strengthen future resilience.

[HEADING] Emergency Response Experience

[TEXT] CCM's emergency response capabilities were tested and strengthened during both the COVID- 19 pandemic and the 2023 Maui Wildfires. During the pandemic, the center rapidly implemented infection control protocols, telehealth expansion, organization-wide staff training on infection control, and community outreach programs to maintain continuity of care for high-risk populations.

[TEXT] In August 2023, during the Maui Wildfires, the health center activated its Internal Command Center to coordinate staffing, medical outreach, and resource deployment. CCM provided the

The health center expanded OB/GYN and behavioral health capacity to address the surge in prenatal and trauma-related need sand collaborated closely with the County of Maui, Maui Health, and other community partners to meet the surge in healthcare needs. Community Health Workers supported these efforts by assisting with the coordination of medication refills, chronic disease management, and distribution of essential supplies.

[TEXT] 6. Competing continuation applicants: Citing your UDS data for the number of unduplicated patients served in calendar year 2024, describe factors that have affected your patient trend since your last SAC application. Explain any downward trend in your total unduplicated patients.

[TEXT] According to the 2024 UDS, CCM served 13,471 unduplicated patients, reflecting an overall increase since the last SAC application. Several key factors contributed to this upward trend.

[TEXT] The Maui wildfires of August 2023 led to widespread displacement, job loss, and economic hardship. Many residents relocated to Central Maui, resulting in greater demand for primary and behavioral health services at CCM's main and satellite sites. Loss of employment and housing also increased Medicaid enrollment among affected families and individuals newly qualifying for coverage.

[TEXT] In addition, CCM experienced a significant increase in obstetric patients following the closure of a private obstetrics practice and the island's broader OB crisis, making CCM the only non-Kaiser OB provider. This drove growth in prenatal and perinatal visits and required expansion of provider FTEs and sonography services.

[TEXT] The rise in patients could also be influenced by limited appointment availability at other clinics, as the island's high cost of living has contributed to ongoing provider shortages.

[HEADING] IMPACT/ EVALUATIVE MEASURES

[TEXT] 1. Describe how your Quality Improvement/Quality Assurance (QI/QA) program:

[TEXT] a. Follows clinical guidelines and standards of care.

[TEXT] CCMs Quality Improvement / Quality Assurance (QI/QA) program is designed to ensure safe, effective, patient-centered high-quality care while addressing the unique needs of the community. The program aligns with nationally recognized evidence-based clinical guidelines, including recommendations and standards of care organizations such as:

[TEXT] · Centers for Disease Control (CDC

[TEXT] · Healthcare Effectiveness Data and Information Set (HEDIS)

[TEXT] · Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) Clearinghouse of Clinical Measures

[TEXT] · National Quality Forum (NQF)

[TEXT] · Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA)

[TEXT] · Institute of Medicine (IOM)

[TEXT] · Uniform Data System (UDS)

[HEADING] · U.S. Preventive Services Task Force

[TEXT] These guidelines are integrated into our electronic health record (EHR) workflows to support consistent clinical decision-making. Ongoing provider education, peer views, and patient chart audits ensure that care delivery reflects current standards of care and identifies areas of improvement.

[TEXT] These practices align with the standards of the Patient-Centered Medical Home (PCMH) care model set by the National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA).

[HEADING] b. Addresses patient safety.

[TEXT] Patient safety is an integral part of CCMs QI/QA program, where a culture of safety is maintained through incident reporting, root cause analysis, and regular safety reviews the provider, care team, and organizational level. Multidisciplinary care reviews, safety huddles, and high-risk patient review meetings provide structured opportunities to monitor safety events and data that allow for improvement opportunities and to implement corrective actions.

[TEXT] The Quality and Risk Management (QRM) Policy establishes a process for identifying, analyzing, and following up on all safety incidents. Events are classified into three levels of severity:

[TEXT] 1. Adverse Events: An undesired outcome or occurrence not expected within the normal course of care, treatment, disease process, condition of the patient, or delivery of services.

[TEXT] 2. Sentinel Event: A major patient safety event (no primarily related to the natural course of the patient's illness or underlying condition) that results in death, permanent harm, or severe or temporary harm with an intervention required to sustain life.

[TEXT] 3. Near Miss: An event or situation that could have resulted in a major safety event, such as death or permanent harm, with an intervention required to sustain life but did not, either by chance or timely intervention.

[TEXT] CCM fosters a culture where all employees are encouraged and empowered to raise safety concerns. Staff are also required to comply with the Incident Reporting Policy, which outlines specific timelines for submission: Near Miss (within 24 hours), Adverse Event (within 2 hours), and Sentinel Event (immediately).

[TEXT] Reports are submitted using a standardized Incident Report Form, accessible to all employees, where reports are then routed to the appropriate department manager, who determines the severity level and addresses an initial resolution. The Quality Manager and Director of Clinical Operations (CDO) are responsible for tracking and ensuring that appropriate follow-up occurs on each incident, with a monthly report to the Chief Medical Officer (CMO) and the Quality and Risk Committee. A sentinel event or a near miss will prompt a Root Cause Analysis (RCA) by the DCO, who will then coordinate an action plan with the CMO. This structured process reinforces accountability, transparency, and continuous learning across the organization to create a culture of safety.

[TEXT] Staff are trained on infection control, emergency preparedness, and risk management with systems in place to track compliance and outcomes.

[HEADING] c. Improves patient experience and satisfaction.

[TEXT] CCM measures patient satisfaction through quarterly surveys that are administered to capture feedback on how well patient needs are being met and to identify opportunities for quality improvement. Patients may complete surveys anonymously by paper or electronically over the course of four weeks. Translation and interpreter support are provided as needed to ensure accessibility for all languages spoken in the community. To encourage participation, staff in all departments are asked to collect surveys from patients they encounter during the survey window. Once complete, results are compiled by the Director of Clinical Operations and shared with staff and the Board of Directors to support transparency and accountability.

[TEXT] In addition, the Patient Complaint and Grievance Policy ensures that concerns are addressed in a timely and consistent manner. Patients are informed of their rights and responsibilities through materials included in their welcome packet, posted on the clinic website, and displayed throughout clinic sites. Complaints and grievances are tracked and monitored by the Director of Clinical Operations, who oversees corrective actions and process improvements when issues are identified. Monthly reports are reviewed by the Quality and Risk Committee to ensure trends are analyzed, follow-up is documented, and systematic improvements are implemented.

[HEADING] d. Uses systems such as electronic health records or population management systems to monitor and track risk factors that impact health.

[TEXT] In April 2024, CCM transitioned EHRs from Athena Practice to Epic. This implementation represents a significant investment in advancing quality and patient care, data accessibility, and population health management capabilities. Epic's comprehensive functionality supports the health center by offering integrated registries, care gap alerts, and real-time dashboards that enable providers to proactively monitor chronic disease outcomes, preventative care compliance, and risk factors such as hypertension, diabetes, and behavioral health conditions.

[TEXT] Epic also improves interoperability, allowing the exchange of clinical information with hospitals, specialists, and community providers. Through Care Everywhere, providers can access patient records from other health systems nationwide, ensuring continuity of care and improving safety during transitions of care. Population health tools within Epic allow us to stratify patients by risk, address social determinants of health, and conduct targeted outreach to high need and high risk groups. These enhanced capabilities strengthen our QI/QA program by providing more accurate, actionable data to guide clinical decision-making and organizational improvement efforts.

[HEADING] 2. Describe how you will improve clinical quality and health outcomes within your patient population, including within the following specified areas:

[TEXT] CCM is committed to continuous quality improvement through data-driven performance monitoring, multidisciplinary collaboration, and evidence-based care. Quality and Data teams work closely with providers, CHWs, and clinical leaders to track UDS and internal performance

[TEXT] measures, identify care gaps, and implement targeted interventions. Regular reviews of outcomes data support timely follow-up, staff training, and workflow adjustments that enhance patient care, improve population health, and advance health equity in the community.

[HEADING] a. Body Mass Index (BMI) screening and follow-up plan

[TEXT] CCMs care teams routinely measure each patient's weight and BMI at every visit. When BMI results fall outside the normal range, providers offer brief interventions and refer patients to nutrition services for individualized counseling. The Data Analyst and Quality and Risk Manager provide training and ongoing monitoring to ensure accurate EHR documentation and adherence to follow-up protocols. Department leaders meet bi-weekly with the Quality team to review data trends, discuss barriers, and identify opportunities for continuous improvement in weight management and patient education.

[HEADING] b. Breast, cervical, and colorectal cancer screenings

[HEADING] Breast Cancer Screenings

[TEXT] The Quality Coordinator and care teams actively identify and reach out to patients who are due for mammograms. Using EHR data reports, care teams review patient panels to determine those due to screening, contact them for scheduling, and document outreach efforts. Mammogram orders are placed directly by the care team to streamline access. The Data Analyst and Quality Department review screening data every two months with department leaders to assess compliance and track progress toward UDS and internal performance benchmarks.

[HEADING] Cervical Cancer Screenings

[TEXT] CCMs Adult Medicine and OB departments collaborate to improve cervical cancer screening rates through proactive patient identification and coordination. Quality Coordinators identify eligible patients prior to visits, request historical records for Pap smears and HPV testing, and conduct outreach to schedule overdue screenings. Test results are reconciled through EHR workflows and tracked to ensure appropriate follow-up. Coordination with the Health Information Technology (HIT) team ensures accuracy of documentation and completeness of results within patient records.

[HEADING] Colorectal Cancer Screening

[TEXT] Quality Coordinators utilize provider panels and EHR data to identify patients due for colorectal cancer screening and conduct targeted outreach. The care team discusses screening options during eligible visits and places orders for either FIT kits, colonoscopies, or Cologuard as appropriate. Exact Sciences (Cologuard) also directly contacts patients once the provider orders are received to support completion. The HIT and Quality teams collaborate to reconcile screening results, close care and data gaps, and ensure timely documentation in the EHR. Monthly review meetings help sustain improvement efforts and address any workflow barriers.

[HEADING] d. Diabetes and Hypertension Control

[TEXT] Care teams at CCM actively monitor patients with diabetes and hypertension through ongoing EHR tracking, care coordination, and patient education. Providers review lab results and blood pressure readings at each visit, offering medication adjustments and self-management support as needed. The Quality and Data teams regularly analyze performance data to identify trends and

[TEXT] ensure adherence to clinical guidelines. Targeted interventions such as nurse follow-up calls, CHW outreach, and referrals to nutrition counseling are used to help patients achieve optimal control and improve overall health outcomes.

[HEADING] e. Screening for Depression and Follow-up Planning, including Depression Remission

[TEXT] Each care team, including Community Health Workers (CHWs), conducts depression screenings at every patient visit using the PHQ-9 tool. Care teams ensure screenings are completed for all eligible patients and track follow-up appointments for those with elevated scores. Data Analysts validate that results and remission codes are accurately captured in the EHR. When necessary, care management staff conduct follow-up assessments by phone. The Quality and Data teams meet bi-monthly with department leaders to review depression screening and remission data, discuss challenges, and identify improvement opportunities.

[HEADING] f. Tobacco Use Screening and Cessation Intervention

[TEXT] All care teams perform tobacco use screening during patient visits and document results in the EHR. Providers refer patients who use tobacco to the Tobacco Specialist for individualized counseling and cessation support. The Clinical Operations Specialist ensures timely referrals, while the Quality and Data teams monitor documentation accuracy and follow-up completion. Educational resources and warm handoffs help strengthen patient engagement in quitting efforts. Continuous review of tobacco screening data supports consistent improvement across all service sites.

[TEXT] e. Weight Assessment and Counseling for Nutrition and Physical Activity for Children and Adolescents

[TEXT] Care teams use weight management education and counseling as a standard part of pediatric visits, documenting assessments and guidance through Bright Futures templates and smart phrase tools in the EHR. Providers counsel on nutrition and physical activity, and refer patients to Nutrition Services as appropriate. Staff perform warm handoffs for high-risk patients to ensure continuity of care. The Quality and Data teams meet every two months with department leaders to evaluate progress, review documentation consistency, and identify strategies to enhance patient and family engagement in healthy lifestyle practices.

[TEXT] Other - Clinic Mortgage Interest

[HEADING] BY- LAWS OF Community Clinic of Maui, Inc. Article I-Name and Principal Office

[TEXT] 1. The name of this Corporation shall be COMMUNITY CLINIC OF MAUI, INC.

[TEXT] 2. The principal office of the Community Clinic of Maui, Inc. (CCM) shall be at such location determined by the Board of Directors.

[HEADING] Article II - Purpose

[TEXT] 1. The Community Clinic of Maui, Inc. has incorporated to obtain all of the powers, benefits and privileges secured by law to incorporated bodies in order that it may hold property and do and perform such acts and things as may be necessary or convenient in carrying out its purposes as contained in Article IV of its Articles of Incorporation.

[TEXT] 2. The Corporation is organized for the purpose of providing primary health care services and health promotion and disease prevention services to residents of Maui County.

[TEXT] 3. The Corporation is organized to do any act or thing incidental to or connected with the forgoing purposes or in advancement thereof, but not for pecuniary profit or connected to financial gain of its directors, or officers, except as permitted under Chapter 414D, Hawaii Revised Statutes.

[TEXT] 4. The Corporation is organized exclusively for charitable, educational and scientific purposes, including for such purposes, the making of distributions to organizations that qualify as exempt organizations under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, or the corresponding section of any future code.

[HEADING] Article III-Objectives

[TEXT] 1. To accomplish its objectives, the Corporation, not limited to any or all of the following, but limited by its Articles of Incorporation, may:

[TEXT] a. Provide or assist in providing needed health services in the County of Maui, as well as other areas.

[TEXT] b. Cooperate with public, voluntary, and private agencies and organizations, including sharing non-confidential information, facilities, and staff.

[TEXT] c. Maintain relationships, as appropriate, with professional and community organizations and groups.

[TEXT] d. Participate in the training of professional and volunteer personnel and in research, conferences, and scientific meetings, as may be beneficial to the purposes and objectives of the Corporation.

[TEXT] 2. Definitions:

[TEXT] a. The Community Clinic of Maui, Inc., may be referred to in these bylaws as "Health Center, "or "Corporation."

[TEXT] b. The term "Board of Directors" may be referred to in these bylaws as "Board".

[TEXT] 3. Nondiscrimination All affairs of the Board and Health Center shall be carried on without discrimination as to race, sex, creed, age, color, marital status, sexual orientation, disability, or national origin.

[HEADING] Article IV-Membership

[TEXT] 1. The Corporation has no members.

[HEADING] Article V- Meetings and Elections

[TEXT] 1. Annual Meeting

[TEXT] There shall be an Annual Meeting of the Board of Directors at such time and place as the directors shall determine.

[TEXT] The Annual Meeting shall include:

[TEXT] a. Electing the directors,

[TEXT] b. Electing the officers, and

[TEXT] c. Hearing the annual reports of the Board and the Chief Executive Officer.

[TEXT] In the event of postponement or failure to call an Annual Meeting, a meeting may be called later to perform the duties required of the Annual Meeting. All acts and doings of the Corporation or its officers performed in the interim shall be of full force and effect.

[TEXT] 2. Regular meetings of the Board at which a quorum is present shall be held monthly.

[TEXT] 3. Special and/or emergency meetings of the Board may be called by the President or upon written request of four (4) Board members. Special and/or emergency meetings are called when time is of the essence.

[TEXT] 4. Nominations and Elections

[TEXT] The Nominating Committee chairman will submit to the Board at the Annual Meeting, the slate of nominees willing to serve as new directors and as officers.

[TEXT] The Chairman of the Nominating Committee will recognize nominations made from the floor or through a petition signed by five (5) directors and presented to the Nominating Committee. Such nomination in every case must be with the consent of the person nominated.

[TEXT] A majority vote of those present shall elect. Election shall be by ballot unless otherwise decided at the Annual Meeting by the majority of directors eligible to vote.

[TEXT] 5. Quorum

[TEXT] The majority of all seated directors of the Board shall constitute a quorum to transact business, and, in order to be valid, any act or business must receive the approval of a majority of directors present at a meeting, in person, by conference call or telecommunication, at which a quorum exists.

[TEXT] 6. Notice of Meetings

[TEXT] Notice of a time and place of meeting shall be given at least seven (7) days in advance of

[TEXT] the annual or regular meetings. Notice of a special meeting may be very short, with a minimum of one (1) day to call a meeting. Notice shall be delivered in person, by telephone or by mail to each director. Oral notice is effective when communicated. If mailed, notice shall be deemed to be delivered when deposited in the United States mail. Notice may also be given to any director by electronic transmission, provided that the director shall have consented to receive notice by electronic transmission. Any consent to receive notice by electronic transmission (i) shall be revocable by the director by written notice to the Corporation, and (ii) shall be deemed to be revoked if the Corporation is unable to deliver by electronic transmission two consecutive notices. Notice given by electronic transmission shall be deemed given (i) when directed to an electronic mail address at which the director has consented to receive notice, if transmitted by electronic mail, (ii) when directed to a number at which the director has consented to receive notice, if transmitted by facsimile telecommunication, and (iii) when directed to the director, if transmitted by any other form of electronic transmission. Any director may waive notice of any meeting provided such waiver is made in writing and signed by the director entitled to the notice or is transmitted by electronic transmission, and delivered to the Corporation for inclusion in the minutes or corporate records.

[HEADING] 7. Meeting Governance

[TEXT] a. All Board meetings, including the Annual Meeting and committee meetings, shall be governed by the current "Robert's Rules of Order, Revised".

[TEXT] b. A majority vote of those present and voting at a meeting at which a quorum exists shall decide the conduct of business.

[TEXT] c. At all meetings of the Board, every voting member participating in the meeting shall have the right to vote. Voting by proxy shall not be permitted.

[TEXT] d. During any meeting, the Board of Directors may choose to enter into an "executive session", at which time only the directors and any invited guests shall be allowed in the session, for such purposes as the Board deems necessary, including, but not limited to, discussion of litigation (actual or threatened), discussion of personnel, evaluation of the Health Center's Chief Executive Officer, receipt of the annual audit, etc.

[HEADING] 8. Place of Meeting

[TEXT] The place of the meetings of the Board of Directors shall be the Corporation's principal office or such other location as shall be stated in the call for meeting.

[TEXT] 9. Minutes

[TEXT] Minutes shall be kept of all Board and committee meetings that verify and document the Board's functioning including recording of major actions and decisions by the Board. The minutes of each Board meeting shall be approved by vote of the Board at the next monthly Board meeting and shall be stored at the Corporations' principal office, consistent with Article VII, Section 7(d) of these Bylaws.

[HEADING] 10. Adjournment

[TEXT] In the absence of quorum at the date, time and place of a meeting duly called and held, the presiding officer or a majority of the directors present may adjourn the meeting from time to time without further notice and may convene or reconvene the meeting when a quorum shall be present.

[HEADING] Article VI-Directors

[TEXT] 1. The Corporation shall be governed by a Board of Directors, whose members shall number

[TEXT] not less than nine (9) nor more than eighteen (18), who shall exercise all the powers of the Corporation except as provided otherwise in the Articles of Incorporation or the By-laws.

[TEXT] a. A majority of the Board of Directors shall be comprised of persons who are served by the Health Center and who, as a group, represent the individuals served by the Health Center, in terms of demographic factors such as race, ethnicity and gender ("consumer directors"). Consumer directors must be current registered patients of the Health Center and must have accessed the Health Center in the past twenty-four (24) months to receive at least one or more service(s) that generated a health center visit, where both the service(s) and the site at which the service(s) was received are within the Health Center's federally-approved scope of project. A legal guardian of a consumer who is a dependent child or adult, a person who has legal authority to make health care decisions on behalf of a consumer, or a legal sponsor of an immigrant, may also be considered a Consumer director.

[TEXT] b. The remainder of the Board of Directors ("non-consumer directors") shall be representative of the community in which the Health Center's catchment area is located, either by living or working in, or having a demonstrable connection to, the community or service area, and shall be comprised of persons having a broad range of skills and expertise in areas such as community affairs, local government, finance and banking, legal affairs, trade unions, other commercial and industrial concerns, or social service agencies.

[TEXT] c. No more than one-half (1/2) of the non-consumer directors may derive more than 10% of their annual income from the health care industry.

[TEXT] d. No member of the Board shall be an employee of the Health Center, or spouse or child, parent, brother or sister, by blood, marriage or adoption, of such an employee, compliance with which will be periodically verified by the Health Center.

[TEXT] 2. Directors shall be elected at the Annual Meeting of the Board of Directors or at a special meeting called for that purpose and shall begin their terms at the close of the meeting at which they were selected. Directors shall serve for a term of three (3) years each and may be re-elected to successive terms. No other entity, committee or individual other than the full Board shall have authority to select the majority of the directors or a majority of the non- consumer directors.

[TEXT] 3. At any annual, regular, or special meeting of the Board at which a quorum is present, any director may be removed for cause or without cause by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the directors then in office. The absence of a director from two (2) consecutive meetings, whether excused or not, may constitute cause for removal of that director from the Board. The director subject to removal shall be given at least seven (7) days written notice before the meeting at which the vote on removal shall be taken. No other entity, committee or individual other than the full Board shall have authority to remove any director not appointed by such third party.

[TEXT] 4. Any director may resign at any time by delivering a written resignation to the President of the Board of Directors. If the President is the resigning director, written notice shall be given to the Secretary. Such resignation shall be effective upon receipt, unless otherwise provided by the terms thereof.

[TEXT] 5. Vacancies on the Board occurring between annual meetings may be filled by the Board, after hearing the recommendations of the Nominating Committee. New members so elected shall hold office for the unexpired term.

[TEXT] 6. Execution of Instruments/Authorized Signatures

[TEXT] All checks, drafts, notes, bonds, acceptances, deeds, leases, contracts, and all other instruments shall be signed by such person or persons as shall be provided by general or special resolution of the Board of Directors, and in the absence of any such general or special resolution applicable to any such instrument, then such instrument shall be signed by the President or by any two other officers of the Corporation.

[HEADING] 7. Duties of the Board of Directors shall include:

[TEXT] a. Oversight responsibility for the conduct of the business of the Corporation and the care of its property and funds.

[TEXT] b. Determination, review, and revision of personnel policies and procedures, including selection and dismissal procedures, salary and benefit scales, and equal opportunity practices.

[TEXT] c. Adoption of financial management and accounting systems and practices, including a system to assure accountability for grant-related resources, and review and approval of (i) the annual capital and operating budgets (including the uses of the federal grant and non-grant funds); (ii) Health Center priorities; (iii) eligibility for services (including eligibility criteria for sliding fee discount and partial payment schedules pursuant to the sliding fee discount program); (iv) billing and collection policies; and (v) long-range financial planning.

[TEXT] d. Monitoring the financial status of the Health Center, including obtaining finances; approving the selection of an independent auditor; annually authorizing, receiving, reviewing and officially accepting the annual audit report; and ensuring that appropriate follow-up actions are taken.

[TEXT] e. Approval of the Health Center's grant application, as well as other applications and material requests to government agencies related to the Health Center's federal scope of project, including but not limited to Change in Scope requests submitted to the Health Resources and Services Administration.

[TEXT] f. Adoption of health care policies, including review and approval of the (I) scope and availability of program services compared to current needs and resources, including decisions to sub-award or contract for a substantial portion of the services; (ii) locations and hours of operation; (iii) quality of care audit procedures and the Health Center's quality improvement / assurance plan; and (iv) a process for the Health Center's staff to hear and resolve patient grievances.

[TEXT] g. Conducting of long-range strategic planning at least once every three years, which, at a minimum, will address financial management and capital expenditure needs.

[TEXT] h. Evaluation of Health Center activities and performance based on Quality Improvement / Assurance assessments and other information received from the Health Center's management, including (i) service utilization patterns; (ii) productivity of the Health Center (including efficiency and effectiveness of the Health Center); (iii) patient satisfaction (including how patient grievances were addressed); and (iv) achievement of project objectives and annual and long-term goals.

[TEXT] i. Election of Board members and officers, upon recommendation of the Nominating Committee.

[TEXT] j. Engagement of the services of a Chief Executive Officer, who shall be an ex-officio, nonvoting member of the Board and attend all Board meetings as such, and who shall be responsible to the Board for the day-to-day operations and activities of the Corporation - refer to Article VIII. The Board shall approve the selection of the Chief Executive Officer, review his/her performance at least annually, and approve his/her dismissal.

[TEXT] k. Assuring that the Health Center operates in compliance with applicable federal, state and local laws and regulations.

[TEXT] No individual director shall act for the Board of Directors except as may be specifically authorized by the Board. No other entity, committee or individual other than the full Board shall reserve approval or veto authority over the Board's decision-making with respect to the aforementioned required authorities and duties.

[TEXT] 8. Board members shall not receive any monetary payment or services in exchange for membership on the Board. Reimbursement or stipends for reasonable expenses, incurred while conducting official Corporation business or while traveling to and from Board meetings, shall be permissible.

[TEXT] 9. The directors shall be divided into three classes. Each class will consist, as nearly equal as possible, of one-third of the number of directors then constituting the entire Board of Directors. The term of office of the first class shall expire at the annual meeting next ensuing. The term of office of the second class shall expire one year thereafter. The term of office of the third class shall expire two years thereafter. At each succeeding annual election, the directors elected shall be chosen for a full term of three years to succeed those whose terms expire.

[TEXT] 10. General Standards for Directors. a. A director shall discharge the director's duties as a director, including the director's duties as a member of a committee:

[TEXT] (1) In good faith; (2) With the care an ordinarily prudent person in a like position would exercise under similar circumstances; and

[TEXT] (3) In a manner the director reasonably believes to be in the best interests of the Corporation.

[TEXT] b. In discharging the director's duties, a director is entitled to rely on information, opinions, reports, or statements, including financial statements and other financial data, if prepared or presented by:

[TEXT] (1) One or more officers or employees of the Corporation whom the director reasonably believes to be reliable and competent in the matters presented;

[TEXT] (2) Legal counsel, public accountants, or other persons as to matters the director reasonably believes are within the person's professional or expert competence; or

[TEXT] (3) A committee of the Board of which the director is not a member, as to matters within its jurisdiction, if the director reasonably believes the committee merits confidence.

[TEXT] c. A director is not acting in good faith if the director has knowledge concerning the matter in question that makes reliance otherwise permitted by subsection (b) unwarranted.

[TEXT] d. A director is not liable to the Corporation or any other person for any action taken or not taken as a director, if the director acted in compliance with this section.

[TEXT] e. A director shall not be deemed to be a trustee with respect to the Corporation or with respect to any property held or administered by the Corporation, including without limit, property that may be subject to restrictions imposed by the donor or transferor of the property.

[TEXT] f. Any person who serves as a director of the Corporation without remuneration or expectation of remuneration shall not be liable for damage, injury, or loss caused by or resulting from the person's performance of, or failure to perform duties of, the position to which the person was elected or appointed, unless the person was grossly negligent in the performance of, or failure to perform, such duties. For purposes of this section, remuneration does not include indemnification of reasonable travel expenses and indemnification or insurance for actions as a director as allowed by sections 414D-159 to 414D-167.

[TEXT] 11. Standards of Conduct / Conflict of Interest

[TEXT] The Board shall adopt, periodically review and as necessary revise a Standards of Conduct or Conflict of Interest Policy that addresses, among other things, conflicts of interest or the appearance of such conflicts by directors, employees, agents (or any member of his/her immediate family, his/her business partner, or an organization that employs or is about to employ any of such parties) and others providing services/goods to the Corporation. Specifically, such standards or policy shall (i) require written disclosure of actual or potential conflicts and (ii) prohibit individuals with a real or apparent conflict of interest with respect to a specific transaction or contract supported by federal funds, in whole or in part, from participating in the selection, award and/or administration of such transaction or contract. Such standards or policy, at a minimum, shall also: (i) prohibit directors, employees and agents from soliciting or accepting gifts, gratuities, favors or anything of monetary value for private financial gain from contractors or parties to sub-agreements; (ii) set forth policies to maintain the confidentiality of proprietary and other corporate information (i.e. any information received as the result of being a director, employee, contractor or other agent of the Corporation); and (iii) impose and enforce disciplinary actions for violations of the standards.

[TEXT] 12. The number of directors to be elected at each annual meeting shall be sufficient to fill all vacancies to constitute the minimum number of authorized directors occurring by expiration of terms or by other reasons.

[HEADING] Article VII-Officers

[TEXT] 1. The officers shall be a President, an Immediate Past President, a Vice President, a Secretary and a Treasurer.

[TEXT] 2. The officers (other than the Immediate Past President) shall be elected annually by the Board from its membership and shall serve for one year beginning at the close of the Annual Meeting, or until their successors are elected. The most recent preceding President shall serve as the Immediate Past President.

[TEXT] 3. The officers shall perform the duties usually pertaining to their respective offices, and such other duties as the directors from time to time may require and direct.

[TEXT] 4. At any annual, regular, or special meeting of the Board at which a quorum is present, any officer may be removed from his office for cause or without cause by a vote of the majority of the remaining directors. The officer subject to removal shall be given at least seven (7) days written notice before the meeting at which the vote on removal shall be taken.

[TEXT] 5. Any officer may resign at any time by delivering a written resignation to the President of the Board of Directors. If the President is the resigning officer, written notice shall be given to the Secretary. Such resignation shall be effective upon receipt, unless otherwise provided by the terms thereof.

[TEXT] 8. Duties of Officers:

[TEXT] a. President: The President of the Corporation shall have the power to sign contracts, notes, minutes of meetings, and all other instruments approved by the Board of Directors. No other entity, committee or individual other than the full Board shall have authority to select the Board President.

[TEXT] b. Immediate Past President. The Immediate Past President shall, upon request of the President, assist the President and shall perform such other duties as determined by the Board.

[TEXT] c. Vice President: The Vice President will provide assistance to each officer, as necessary, or as directed by the President, to further the purposes of the Corporation. In case of the absence of the President from any meeting of the Board of Directors, the Vice President will preside. The Vice President shall also perform other duties as may be required by the Board and these By-laws.

[TEXT] d. Secretary: The Secretary, aided by staff, will be responsible for giving notice of all meetings of the Board, for recording, distributing and maintaining custody of the minutes of all meetings of the Executive Committee and Board, and shall undertake such acts as may be necessary to keep the Corporation in good standing with the State of Hawai'i and in any jurisdiction approved by the Board of Directors for the conduct of corporate activities.

[TEXT] e. The Treasurer will serve on the Finance Committee and, with the aid of the staff, maintain supervision of the books and records of account of the Corporation. Such books and records shall be located at the principal office of the Corporation. Subject to the direction of the Finance Committee, the Treasurer shall have charge of and be responsible for all funds and securities of the Corporation. The Treasurer shall render to the Board at its regular meetings, or when the Board so requires, an account of all the transactions as Treasurer and of the financial conditions of the Corporation.

[TEXT] d. An officer is not liable to the Corporation or other person for any action taken or not taken as an officer, if the officer acted in compliance with this section.

[TEXT] e. Any person who serves as an officer to the Corporation without remuneration or expectation of remuneration shall not be liable for damage, injury, or loss caused by or resulting from the person's performance of or failure to perform duties of the position to which the person was appointed, unless the person was grossly negligent in the performance of or failure to perform the duties. For purposes of this section, remuneration does not include indemnification of reasonable travel expenses and indemnification or insurance for actions as an officer as allowed by sections 414D-159 to 414D-167.

[HEADING] Article VIII -Chief Executive Officer

[TEXT] 1. The Board shall hire a Chief Executive Officer, who will report and be accountable to the Board and will be responsible for the daily operations of the Corporation.

[TEXT] 2. The Chief Executive Officer shall be an ex-officio, nonvoting member of the Board and shall attend meetings of the Board of Directors, the Executive Committee, and other standing and special / ad hoc committees as needed.

[TEXT] 3. The Chief Executive Officer shall have the authority to administer the Corporation in keeping with the purposes, policies, and procedures established by the Board of Directors.

[TEXT] 4. The Chief Executive Officer shall maintain the funds of the Corporation in one or more accounts designated or approved by the Board of Directors. He or she shall have the authority to make payments for all ordinary operating expenses of the Corporation.

[TEXT] 5. The Chief Executive Officer shall recruit, hire, supervise, evaluate, terminate, and fix the terms of compensation, benefits, duties, and responsibilities of all employees other than for him/herself in accordance with a Board approved personnel policy.

[HEADING] Article X- Action Without Meeting and Telephone Meetings

[TEXT] 1. To the full extent permitted by law, any action required or permitted to be taken at any meeting of the Board or any committee thereof may be taken by unanimous written consent of the directors or of such committee, as the case may be, without such meeting.

Unless prohibited by the Articles of Incorporation and subject to the provisions herein relating to notice, the directors of the Board or any committee designated thereby may participate in a meeting of such Board or committee by means of a conference telephone or similar communications equipment by means of which all persons participating in the meeting can hear one another. Although participation by such means shall constitute presence in person at a meeting, participation in person is still preferred and encouraged.

The indemnification provided for in this Article shall continue as to any person who has ceased to be a director, officer, employee or agent of the Corporation and shall inure to the benefit of such person's heirs, personal representatives, executors and administrators.

[HEADING] Article XII - Political Activity

[TEXT] Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code provides that the Corporation may not "participate in, or intervene in (including the publishing or distributing of statements), any political campaign on behalf of (or in opposition to) any candidate for public office." The Corporation is apolitical and non-partisan and is committed to take a neutral position on issues and among all candidates for political office. As an individual citizen, a Board member may engage in political activities so long as such service or activity on his part on behalf of a political candidate or party does not conflict with the performance of his regular duties as a Board member or reflect adversely on the Corporation. Directors may freely express their personal convictions on any political or social issue, but must make it clear that they speak as private citizens and not as representatives of the Corporation.

[HEADING] Article XIII: Annual Audit

[HEADING] 1. Audit

[TEXT] The Corporation will have an annual audit each year within nine months after the end of the fiscal year which shall be performed by an accredited CPA firm.

[HEADING] 2. Audit Committee

[TEXT] The Audit Committee shall review the findings of the auditor and report back to the Board on recommendations for appropriate follow-up actions necessary for the Corporation.

[TEXT] 3. Fiscal Year

[TEXT] The fiscal year of the Corporation shall be July 1 through June 30.

[HEADING] Article XIV: Dissolution

[TEXT] Dissolution of the Corporation may be accomplished as provided by the laws governing non- profit corporations in the State of Hawaii and federal laws governing nonprofit corporations exempt from federal income taxation under the provisions of the Internal Revenue Service

[HEADING] Chief Executive Officer

[HEADING] Primary Function:

[TEXT] The Chief Executive Officer (CEO) is directly employed by the Community Clinic of Maui, Inc. (CCM) and reports to the CCM Board of Directors. The CEO provides executive leadership and overall management of the health center, overseeing key management staff in the day-to-day operations of the organization to ensure delivery of high-quality, accessible, and compliant health services consistent with HRSA's Health Center Program requirements and CCM's mission.

[TEXT] Additionally, the CEO:

[TEXT] · Implements the vision, mission, and strategic priorities established by the Board of Directors.

[TEXT] · Oversees key management staff in the fiscal, clinical, administrative, and operational functions necessary for the Health Center Program project.

[TEXT] · Works with the Chief Financial Officer and Finance Committee to develop and implement the annual budget and sliding fee schedule.

[TEXT] · Directs and evaluates supervisory staff; authorizes hires, terminations, promotions, salaries, and professional development.

[TEXT] · Recommends and administers board-approved policies, including those related to finance, personnel, clinical operations, information technology, quality improvement, and compliance.

[TEXT] · Coordinates and oversees fund development, community outreach, and public relations to advance the organization's goals.

[TEXT] · Serves as liaison to federal, state, and local agencies and negotiates and administers all contracts and insurance agreements.

[TEXT] · Ensures organizational compliance with all federal, state, and local laws, regulations, and Health Center Program requirements.

[TEXT] · Attends and participates in all meetings of the Board of Directors except during executive sessions evaluating CEO performance.

[TEXT] · Provides monthly operational and financial reports and recommendations to the Board.

[TEXT] · Serves as a non-voting, ex-officio resource to the Board of Directors.

[TEXT] · This is a full-time position.

[HEADING] Qualifications:

[TEXT] Education:

[TEXT] · Bachelor's degree in Arts, Science, or a health-related field, or equivalent.

[TEXT] · Master's degree in Public Health, Business/Health Administration, or a related field preferred.

[TEXT] · Equivalent qualifying experience may substitute for required education.

[TEXT] Experience/Skills:

[TEXT] · Minimum four years of specialized or administrative experience with Maui organizations or comparable community-based programs.

[TEXT] · Strong leadership, analytical, and project management skills.

[TEXT] · Excellent verbal and written communication.

[TEXT] · Familiarity with community needs and populations served.

[HEADING] Chief Financial Officer

[HEADING] Primary Function:

[TEXT] The Chief Financial Officer (CFO) is a key member of the executive management team and reports directly to the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the health center. The CFO is responsible for overseeing all financial operations, information systems, and data management to ensure fiscal integrity, regulatory compliance, and the effective use of technology to support patient care and organizational performance. This position also fulfills the responsibilities of the Chief Information Officer (CIO), providing oversight of all information systems, data security, and technology functions.

[TEXT] Essential Duties and Responsibilities:

[TEXT] · Strategic and Financial Planning: Plans and formulates the organization's financial direction; supports tactical initiatives, capital requests, and budgeting processes; provides strategic input on organizational priorities.

[TEXT] · Operations and Information Systems Oversight: Participates in key executive decisions; maintains effective relationships across departments; manages accounting, grants management, information technology, revenue cycle, reception, facilities, and housekeeping; oversees transaction processing systems and information systems infrastructure; ensures compliance with HIPAA and data security standards; leads EHR optimization and data reporting functions; implements operational and technological best practices to enhance efficiency and patient care.

[TEXT] · Finance and Reporting: Oversees the issuance of financial information; prepares financial statements, reports, and key analyses; ensures accuracy of journal entries and reconciliations; presents financial and operational performance to the Board of Directors and management.

[TEXT] · Risk and Compliance Management: Identifies and mitigates financial, technological, and operational risks; ensures internal controls, audit readiness, and compliance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations; oversees insurance coverage and legal coordination; maintains relationships with auditors and responds to findings.

[TEXT] · Funding and Cash Management: Monitors cash flow and forecasts; oversees investments and financing arrangements; manages relationships with banks, vendors, and funding agencies.

[TEXT] · Technology and Data Systems: Provides leadership for information systems planning and implementation; ensures that technology supports quality improvement, reporting (UDS, CQMs, etc.), and organizational goals; coordinates cybersecurity, data integrity, and interoperability with clinical and financial systems.

[TEXT] · This is a full-time position.

[HEADING] Chief Medical Officer

[HEADING] Primary Function:

[TEXT] The Chief Medical Officer (CMO) reports directly to the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) and provides executive oversight of all clinical services. The CMO ensures the delivery of high-quality, evidence-based, and patient-centered care while maintaining compliance with all federal, state, and local regulations. The position leads the development, implementation, and evaluation of clinical policies and procedures to promote excellence in quality, safety, and preventive care across all service lines.

[HEADING] Essential Duties and Responsibilities:

[TEXT] · Provides medical leadership and direct supervision of all clinical providers, ensuring quality, efficiency, and adherence to clinical protocols and standards of care.

[TEXT] · Provides direct patient care, including assessment, diagnosis, treatment, and referral to appropriate specialists or agencies when needed.

[TEXT] · Serves as the clinic's principal medical authority and consultant to staff on clinical issues, policies, and medical best practices.

[TEXT] · Oversees provider recruitment, credentialing, onboarding, and performance management in collaboration with Human Resources and the CEO.

[TEXT] · Coordinates provider scheduling, call coverage, and clinical assignments to ensure adequate access to care.

[TEXT] · Facilitates provider and interdisciplinary team meetings; maintains active communication with executive leadership, the Board of Directors, and key community partners.

[TEXT] · Leads the planning and implementation of clinical strategies aligned with organizational goals, community health priorities, and value-based care initiatives.

[TEXT] · Oversees clinical quality improvement activities, including chart reviews, peer review, and performance monitoring to ensure compliance with HRSA, FTCA, and PCMH standards.

[TEXT] · Participates in the development and monitoring of the clinical budget and ensures efficient use of resources in alignment with organizational priorities.

[TEXT] · Serves as liaison to hospitals, medical societies, educational institutions, and other healthcare organizations to strengthen partnerships and support system-level coordination of care.

[TEXT] · Ensures compliance with infection control, safety, and risk management policies.

[TEXT] · Promotes a culture of trauma-informed, team-based, and patient-centered care that supports provider well-being and professional growth.

[HEADING] Attachment 5. Biographical Sketches for Key Management Staff

[HEADING] Dr John Vaz, Chief Executive Officer

[TEXT] Dr. John Vaz is the CEO of Malama I Ke Ola Health Center, a federally qualified health center serving the island of Maui, apart from Hana. John moved to Maui in 2017, from Washington, D.C., to serve as Malama I Ke Ola's Chief Medical Officer, and in 2022, the health center's Board appointed him as CEO. During his time here, he has had the privilege of building on the health center's innate strengths and mission and implementing daily quality improvement, team- based care, trauma-informed care, and specific models of care for populations facing significant barriers to care. Along with a focus on serving the community, John has a deep passion for growing Mālama I Ke Ola into a learning organization to provide increased opportunities for learning and growth for its dedicated staff. He continues to maintain a clinical practice alongside his administrative duties and provides both internal medicine and infectious disease care to his patient panel.

[TEXT] Before joining Malama I Ke Ola Health Center, John served as both the Site Medical Director and Director of Infectious Disease Services at Chase Brexton Health Care, a large federally qualified health center system in Maryland. His focus involved Viral Hepatitis, HIV care and prevention, substance use recovery, and general primary care.

[TEXT] He completed medical school at St. John's National Academy of Medical Sciences in Bangalore, India, followed by an Internal Medicine Residency at the University of Connecticut and an Infectious Diseases Fellowship at the University of Maryland. In 2021, he earned a Master of Science in Healthcare Administration from the University of Alabama, Birmingham.

[TEXT] Dr. Aaron Altura, Interim Chief Medical Officer

[TEXT] Dr. Aaron Altura has been an OB/GYN physician at Malama I Ke Ola Health Center since January 1996. He has led the OB/GYN department since 2021, overseeing clinical operations, quality improvement, and provider performance. In 2025, he was appointed interim Chief Medical Officer.

[TEXT] He received his medical degree from University of California, Davis School of Medicine and completed his residency in Obstetrics and Gynecology at Louisiana State University Medical Center.

[HEADING] Cassie Savell, Chief Operating Officer

[TEXT] Cassie has been with the Community Clinic of Maui, Inc. (CCM) since 2013 where she has served as Assistant Chief Financial Officer and is currently serving as the Chief Operating Officer and Deputy CEO. With a background in finance and operations, she provides oversight for clinical and administrative operations, program development and grants management.

[TEXT] Cassie holds a Bachelor of Science degree in Finance and Investment Management as well as a Master's in Business Administration, Master's in Health Administration, and a Doctorate in Health Sciences from A.T. Still University. She is also a member of the American College of Healthcare Executives.

[HEADING] Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance

[TEXT] Sliding Fee Discount Program Community Clinic of Maui, Inc. (CCM) operates a uniform Sliding Fee Discount Program (SFDP) that applies to all patients receiving in-scope services, regardless of insurance status, source of income, or ability to pay. The SFDP ensures that financial barriers do not prevent access to care while maintaining compliance with HRSA Health Center Program requirements.

[TEXT] Income is a family's gross income reported for federal income tax purposes including gross wages, social security/disability benefits, child support, retirement benefits, unemployment and other public assistance. The applicant and the number of individuals who qualify as an IRS dependent of the applicant determine family size. This includes the applicant, spouse, dependent children and any other individual that qualifies as a personal exemption for tax reporting purposes. The Organization will use the IRS definition of a dependent to determine family size, even if the applicant does not a file tax return.

[TEXT] CCM updates its Sliding Fee Discount Schedule (SFDS) annually based on the most recent FPG published by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, applying the Hawaii-specific FPG to reflect local cost of living. Eligibility is determined for all patients based solely on documented income and family size. Patients are assessed for SFDS eligibility during registration or at the time of their first visit, with discounts applied immediately upon self- attestation or submission of proof of income. Documentation is verified within 30 days or by the second visit, whichever occurs first.

[TEXT] Patient charges are adjusted according to the SFDS to ensure that no patient pays more than the maximum amount established for their income level and family size. The SFDS is structured in discount categories between 0% and 200% of FPG, with patients above 200% FPG charged the full fee. Community Clinic of Maui administers additional state-funded programs, including the Hawai'i Department of Health Comprehensive Primary Care Services Grant, that may subsidize services for patients with income above 200 % of FPG. These discounts are distinct from and operate outside of the HRSA-funded Sliding Fee Discount Program.

[TEXT] For patients with incomes at or below 100% FPG, CCM applies a nominal charge that is flat, minimal from the perspective of the patient, and not reflective of the full cost of services. This nominal charge ensures administrative efficiency while preserving equitable access. No patient will be denied care based on inability to pay the nominal amount.

[HEADING] Contracts and Subawards

[TEXT] CCM does not currently administer any subawards under its Health Center Program funding. All activities within the HRSA-approved scope of project are carried out directly by CCM staff or through contractual arrangements that do not constitute subrecipient relationships.

[TEXT] Although there are no active subawards, CCM maintains internal controls and written procedures consistent with 45 CFR Part 75 to ensure compliance should subawards occur in the future. These procedures outline the process for pre-award risk assessment, agreement language, fiscal

[TEXT] and programmatic monitoring, and documentation of compliance with all applicable federal requirements.

[TEXT] Prior to entering a new business relationship with a potential contractor or vendor, they must go through the Organization's Suspension and Debarment Process. All new contractors and vendors are reviewed on System for Award Management (SAM): https://sam.gov/. All current contractors and vendors are reviewed annually to ensure their status has not changed.

[TEXT] For existing vendor and contractual relationships, CCM's Procurement and Fiscal Policies ensure that all contracts are reviewed to verify:

[TEXT] . The contractor's activities fall within the HRSA-approved scope of project,

[TEXT] · Costs are allowable, reasonable, and allocable under Federal Cost Principles (2 CFR Part 200, Subpart E), and

[TEXT] · Performance and deliverables align with federal, state, and organizational requirements.

[TEXT] This oversight framework ensures full accountability for federal funds and readiness to manage subawards in compliance with HRSA and other federal regulations if they are established in the future.

[TEXT] Billing and Collections

[TEXT] CCM maintains board-approved billing and collections policies to ensure ethical, transparent, and compliant financial practices that do not create barriers to care.

[TEXT] CCM participates in all major public programs, including Medicare, Medicaid (Quest Integration), and the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP), as well as marketplace and private insurance plans. All patients are screened for insurance eligibility at registration and educated on available public coverage options. Charges for services are based on the board- approved fee schedule which reflects reasonable and locally prevailing rates and serves as the basis for all billing to third-party payers and self-pay patients.

[TEXT] Billing is performed daily for all services rendered. Claims are submitted electronically to Medicare, Medicaid, and other payers in accordance with their program requirements. The Billing Manager oversees reconciliation of accounts receivable, claim resubmissions, and compliance with billing timeliness standards. Denied claims are corrected and resubmitted, and accounts receivable aging is monitored to ensure timely collections.

[TEXT] For self-pay patients, CCM applies the Sliding Fee Discount Program to adjust charges based on income and family size. Patients are encouraged to make payments at the time of service, but monthly statements are issued for any remaining balances.

[TEXT] CCM's Fee Waiver Policy authorizes reductions or waivers of fees under specific, documented hardship circumstances such as loss of employment, medical emergencies, or catastrophic life events. CCM staff evaluate requests and submit recommendations to the CEO or designee for approval. Fee waivers or additional discounts are documented and monitored to ensure consistency, fairness, and compliance.

[TEXT] Article VI - Directors, Section(k)

[TEXT] CCM maintains full governing authority through is Board of Directors (Board) as stated in Article VI, Section 1, whose members are elected annually in accordance with Article VII - Officers. The Board retains governing responsibility for all corporate actions and ensures that all collaborative efforts align with the organization's mission and approved policies. The Board meets monthly to review operational, financial, and quality reports; approve budgets, policies, and grant proposals; and take formal action on all matters requiring Board approval.

[TEXT] The Board retains ultimate decision-making authority for the selection, evaluation, and when necessary, dismissal of the CEO. The CEO may execute agreements and partnerships only within the parameters and policies approved by the Board. Article VI, Section 7(k) states that no individual, entity, or committee has veto power or independent approval authority over the Board's decision-making.

[TEXT] Article V, Section 5 states the majority of all seated directors of the Board shall constitute a quorum to transact business, and, in order to be value, any act or business must receive the approval of a majority of directors present at a meeting, in person, by conference call, or telecommunication, at which a quorum exists. Section 7 states that all voting members present in meetings shall have the right to vote, and no vote by proxy shall be permitted. Vacancies in officer positions are addressed through a defined succession and appointment process outlined in Article VII, Section 6 and 7. Board meetings, including committee meetings are documented through recorded minutes as stated in Article V, Section 9.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Update of Needs Assessment
compliantItems.requirement: The health center completes or updates a needs assessment of the current or proposed population at least once every three years, for the purposes of informing and improving the delivery of health center services. The needs assessment utilizes the most recently available data for the service area and, if applicable, special populations and addresses the following:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validation that the health center completes or updates a needs assessment at least once every three years using current data, addressing access/utilization factors, morbidity/mortality/disparities, and unique health needs.
compliantItems.evidence: "The health center conducts a comprehensive Community Health Needs Assessment (CHNA) every three years, supplemented by annual updates that inform program planning, resource allocation, and strategic priorities." "The assessment incorporates both quantitative and qualitative data. Quantitative sources include HRSA UDS data, Epic data and registry reports, social determinants of health screenings, community-level data from the Hawai'i Department of Health, University of Hawaii Manoa data reports, U.S. Census, and GeoCare Navigator as well as other community-based needs assessment data reports." "Maui's high cost of living and dispersed geography limit access to care, with most health services concentrated in Central Maui and residents in other districts traveling up to 55 miles for appointments. Limited public transit and the high cost of car ownership make transportation a major barrier, especially for low-income households. CCM addresses this through transportation coordination and contracted ride services to help patients reach care."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates a triennial needs assessment using current data, addressing access/utilization, morbidity/mortality/disparities, and unique health needs. We checked: (1) frequency of assessment—SATISFIED: application states a CHNA is conducted every three years with annual updates; (2) use of current data—SATISFIED: multiple recent data sources are cited; (3) all required factors—SATISFIED: explicit discussion of access barriers, morbidity/mortality, disparities, and unique social/environmental needs. All items are addressed with direct evidence, so the requirement is compliant.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Sliding Fee Discount Program Policies
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has board-approved policy(ies) for its sliding fee discount program that apply uniformly to all patients and address the following areas:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validation of board-approved sliding fee discount program policies for uniform application, including definitions, eligibility assessment, SFDS structure, and nominal charge requirements.
compliantItems.evidence: "CCM assesses all patients for Sliding Fee Discount eligibility based solely on income and family size. Patients are informed of the Sliding Fee Discount Program (SFDP) during registration and annually thereafter. Income is a family's gross income reported for federal income tax purposes including gross wages, social security/disability benefits, child support, retirement benefits, unemployment and other public assistance. The applicant and the number of individuals who qualify as an IRS dependent of the applicant determine the family size. This includes the applicant, spouse, dependent children and any other individual that qualifies as a personal exemption for tax reporting purposes. The Organization will use the IRS definition of a dependent to determine family size, even if the applicant does not a file tax return." "CCM's Fee Waiver Policy authorizes reductions or waivers of fees under specific, documented hardship circumstances such as loss of employment, medical emergencies, or catastrophic life events. Other situations that demonstrate that the patient would be unable to pay medical bills and still be able to pay for other basic necessary expenses are also considered. CCM staff evaluate requests and submit recommendations to the CEO or designee for approval of a full waiver, discount, or deferred payment. Fee waivers or additional discounts are documented and monitored to ensure consistency, fairness, and compliance." "Locally prevailing rates or charges, Medicaid cost reports, UDS reports, and other relevant sources are used to inform the cost of services on CCM's fee schedule. CCM applies a flat, nominal charge for patients with incomes at or below 100% of the FPG that does not reflect the actual cost of the service being provided. The setting of the nominal charge is based on input from our Patient Board Members, Patient Satisfaction Surveys, and a review of co-pays and co-insurance associated with Medicare and Medicaid Plans."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates board-approved, uniformly applied sliding fee discount program policies that address definitions of income/family, eligibility assessment, SFDS structure, and nominal charge setting. We checked: (1) definitions of income/family—SATISFIED: explicit IRS-based definitions provided; (2) assessment based only on income/family size—SATISFIED: process described in detail; (3) SFDS structure—SATISFIED: policies and schedule ensure charges are based on ability to pay; (4) nominal charge—SATISFIED: flat, nominal charge set with patient input and not reflecting actual cost. All items are explicitly addressed with direct quotes, so the requirement is compliant.

compliantItems.element: Element c - Sliding Fee for Column I Services
compliantItems.requirement: For services provided directly by the health center (Form 5A: Services Provided, Column I), the health center's SFDS(s) is structured consistent with its policy and provides discounts as follows:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validation that the Sliding Fee Discount Schedule (SFDS) for services provided directly by the health center (Form 5A, Column I) is structured per policy and provides required discounts for patients at or below 100% FPG, partial discounts for 101-200% FPG with at least three pay classes, and no discounts above 200% FPG.
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates (1) a full discount or nominal charge for ≤100% FPG, (2) partial discounts with at least three pay classes for 101-200% FPG, and (3) no discounts above 200% FPG. We checked: (1) full discount/nominal charge for ≤100% FPG—SATISFIED: schedule shows $12.50 nominal charge for code A, (2) partial discounts for 101-200% FPG with at least three pay classes—SATISFIED: codes B, C, D provide three distinct discount classes, (3) no discounts above 200% FPG—SATISFIED: code E is full fee. All items are explicitly addressed in the SFDS table and supporting narrative, so the requirement is compliant.
