compliantItems.element: Element a - Coordination and Integration of Activities
compliantItems.requirement: The health center documents its efforts to collaborate with other providers or programs in the service area, including local hospitals, specialty providers, and social service organizations (including those that serve special populations), to provide access to services not available through the health center in order to support:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validation of documentation of collaborative efforts with other providers/programs to support (a) continuity of care, (b) access to other health/community services, and (c) reduction in non-urgent ED use.
compliantItems.evidence: "Collaboration with Maui Memorial Medical Center supports care transitions for patients frequently accessing the emergency department or discharged without a primary care provider. CCM's care coordination team maintains direct communication with hospital case management to provide follow-up, connect patients with insurance or benefits, and establish ongoing primary care." "CCM partners with Hana Health, Maui's rural FQHC, and Lanai Community Health Center to provide services such as obstetrics and gynecology for patients from East Maui or Lanai. Patients from these health centers may receive care at CCM when services are not available at their home site. When appropriate, Hana Health and Lanai providers coordinate with CCM clinicians via telehealth to reduce unnecessary travel for patients." "CCWs assess social determinants of health and coordinate referrals to housing, food, and social service programs."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates explicit documentation of collaborative efforts with other providers/programs to support (1) continuity of care, (2) access to health/community services, and (3) reduction in non-urgent ED use. We checked for direct evidence for each item. (1) Continuity of care is addressed through formal partnerships and referral coordination with hospitals and other health centers. (2) Access to other services is documented via CHW referrals to housing, food, and social programs. (3) Reduction in non-urgent ED use is supported by direct communication and follow-up with hospital case management. All items are explicitly addressed with direct quotes, so the requirement is compliant.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Board Member Selection and Removal Process
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that specify the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members. This board member selection and removal process does not permit any other entity, committee or individual (other than the board) to select either the board chair or the majority of health center board members, including a majority of the non-patient board members.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validation that the health center has bylaws or other documents specifying the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members, and that no outside entity, committee, or individual (other than the board) can select the board chair or majority of board members.
compliantItems.evidence: "Directors shall be elected at the Annual Meeting of the Board of Directors or at a special meeting called for that purpose and shall begin their terms at the close of the meeting at which they were selected. Directors shall serve for a term of three (3) years each and may be re-elected to successive terms. No other entity, committee or individual other than the full Board shall have authority to select the majority of the directors or a majority of the non-consumer directors. ... At any annual, regular, or special meeting of the Board at which a quorum is present, any director may be removed for cause or without cause by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the directors then in office. ... No other entity, committee or individual other than the full Board shall have authority to remove any director not appointed by such third party."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates explicit bylaws specifying the process for selection and removal of board members, and that only the board (not any outside entity, committee, or individual) may select the board chair or majority of board members. We checked for: (1) board member selection and removal process—SATISFIED: bylaws state directors are elected by the board and only the board can remove directors, (2) restriction on outside entities—SATISFIED: bylaws explicitly prohibit any other entity, committee, or individual from selecting or removing the majority of directors or the board chair. All items are satisfied with clear, direct language in the bylaws; requirement is compliant.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that require the board to be composed as follows:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validated that the health center's bylaws or other documents require the board to meet all HRSA board composition requirements, including size, patient majority, demographic representation, expertise, and conflict of interest.
compliantItems.evidence: "The Corporation shall be governed by a Board of Directors, whose members shall number not less than nine (9) nor more than eighteen (18)... a majority of the Board of Directors shall be comprised of persons who are served by the Health Center and who, as a group, represent the individuals served by the Health Center, in terms of demographic factors such as race, ethnicity and gender... The remainder of the Board of Directors ('non-consumer directors') shall be representative of the community... and shall be comprised of persons having a broad range of skills and expertise in areas such as community affairs, local government, finance and banking, legal affairs, trade unions, other commercial and industrial concerns, or social service agencies... No more than one-half (1/2) of the non-consumer directors may derive more than 10% of their annual income from the health care industry. No member of the Board shall be an employee of the Health Center, or spouse or child, parent, brother or sister, by blood, marriage or adoption, of such an employee, compliance with which will be periodically verified by the Health Center."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates explicit board composition rules in bylaws or other documents. We checked for: (1) board size, (2) patient majority, (3) demographic representation, (4) community representation, (5) expertise, (6) health care industry income limit, and (7) exclusion of employees/immediate family. All items are directly addressed in Article VI of the bylaws, with clear, explicit language matching HRSA requirements. Therefore, all Must Address items are satisfied and the requirement is compliant.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center has documentation that the board is composed of:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validated that the health center's board composition meets HRSA requirements for size, patient majority, demographic representation, special population representation, and non-patient member qualifications.
compliantItems.evidence: "Board is at least 9 and no more than 25 members with either a prescribed number or range of board members" ... "At least 51% of board members are patients served by the health center." ... "Patient members of the board, as a group, represent the individuals served by the health center in terms of demographic factors (for example, sex, race, ethnicity)." ... "Non-patient members are representative of the community served by the health center or the health center's service area." ... "No more than one-half of non-patient board members may earn more than 10% of their annual income from the health care industry."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates explicit documentation that the board has 9-25 members, a patient majority, demographic representation, special population representation, and non-patient member qualifications. We checked: (1) board size—SATISFIED: bylaws state 'not less than nine (9) nor more than eighteen (18)', (2) patient majority—SATISFIED: bylaws and compliance table require at least 51% patient members, (3) demographic representation—SATISFIED: bylaws require patient board members to represent the served population in race, ethnicity, and gender, (4) special population representation—SATISFIED: Form 6A and narrative confirm board includes consumer representatives and expertise relevant to the population, (5) non-patient member qualifications—SATISFIED: bylaws and Form 6A show non-patient members are community representatives with relevant skills, and no more than half earn >10% income from health care. All items are explicitly addressed with direct evidence; requirement is compliant.

notApplicableItems.requirement: In cases where a health center receives an award/designation under section 330(g), 330(h) and/or 330(i), does not receive an award/designation under section 330(e), and requests a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirements, the health center presents to HRSA for review and approval:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: Validation of waiver request for patient majority board composition requirements for health centers not funded under 330(e) but funded under 330(g), (h), or (i).
notApplicableItems.evidence: "Alert: This form is not applicable to you, since you are currently receiving or applying to receive Community Health Center (CHC) funding and/or you have selected 'Tribal' or 'Urban Indian' as the Business Entity in Form 1A."
notApplicableItems.reasoning: The requirement only applies to health centers funded under 330(g), (h), or (i) and NOT under 330(e) that request a waiver of the patient majority board composition. The application (Form 6B) explicitly states this form is not applicable because the organization is receiving or applying for Community Health Center (CHC/330(e)) funding. Therefore, the N/A condition is met and the requirement does not apply. No further compliance evaluation is necessary.
